PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to his news release dated 12 April concerning Ambassador Burke and to the following statement:

QUESTION.PARA: The decision to approve paid special leave was in accordance with the normal terms and conditions applying to all heads of diplomatic missions.

I ask: will the Minister table in the Senate those terms and conditions? To what extent is the Minister's discretion operable in this area? Given the obvious requirement for Ambassador Burke to be present in Australia from time to time for the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters throughout this year and, possibly, even next year, will the provision of special leave be available to him for those other occasions at an approximate cost of $3,000 a week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there is no difficulty about tabling the terms and conditions and I will do that as soon as I have a copy to hand.

ANSWER.PARA: The discretion vested in me so far as special leave is concerned follows from a reference in one paragraph of those terms and conditions to matters which would, in the case of the Public Service generally, be for determination by the Department of Industrial Relations but are, in the case of ambassadors, matters for my determination. Accordingly, special leave-which is one that is applicable for the Public Service generally, and involves an authority vested in the Department of Industrial Relations-is an authority, by virtue of those terms and conditions, vested in me.

That provision is not unique to Mr Burke's terms and conditions. It is a standard clause. The kind of discretion that one exercises in this instance depends wholly on the circumstances of the particular case. There is no obvious pre- cedent to call in aid in this instance. I did so exercise my discretion in this case on the basis of advice tendered to me by my Department which had carefully reviewed the nature of the public and departmental interests as well as, of course, those of Mr Burke himself, involving his coming back to deal with these matters before the Commission.

So far as possible future appearances before the Commission are concerned, I have no information as to what the nature, extent and duration of those subsequent appearances are likely to be. It may be that we will be better informed about that towards the end of the present period of his appearance back in Australia. I simply say that the decisions about that are to be made in all the circumstances as they exist at the time, and no decision has been made to this point, nor any understandings reached, as to the nature of further special leave of this kind.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOADING OF GRAIN VESSELS IN SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to recent press reports about new work arrangements for the loading of grain vessels in South Australia. I ask: can the Minister provide further details of any of these changes and their impact on the grain industry?
—Are you going to ask him to tell us about Conaust?

—Why does Senator Kemp not ask that question himself? I am pleased to advise the Senate that, following reforms in the grain handling terminals generally which resulted in manpower reductions of between 50 and 80 per cent at those terminals, agreement was reached last week in South Australia to expedite a process of continuous pour in South Australian grain ports. This will enable pours of 14 continuous hours to be achieved, which will add greatly to the further efficiency that is being achieved in waterfront reform in those ports, and I understand that that has been warmly welcomed by the industry.

—Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade deny statements by Mr Alan Renouf, the former head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, that no ambassador should be in Mr Burke's position of being embroiled in domestic political controversy and that a career diplomat would not be given the same degree of latitude? Does the Minister also deny Mr Renouf's assertion that Mr Burke could not be an effective representative in his present circumstances?
—It is not a matter of denying anything Mr Renouf said; it is a matter of not sharing his judgment.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Australian Financial Review on 2 April 1991 by Alan Kohler, which points out that the equity base of the Adsteam group of companies has been wiped out? The article states that in six months the shareholders of these companies have lost $3.5 billion, almost entirely because of the decline in value of cross-shareholdings in each other company, which predated the last balance date. The article states also that the equity collapse was hidden by its exploitation of hopelessly inadequate accounting and reporting rules. Therefore, what action is the Government taking, in light of the Adsteam group of companies collapse, to require companies to consolidate the accounts of entities they control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should not comment on the specific case because legal proceedings are afoot. I can comment on some of the wider implications of the matters of concern that Senator Schacht has raised and the Government's plans in that area. It is true that current law requires companies to produce group accounts only in relation to their subsidiary companies. It does not cover unincorporated entities like trusts or partnerships. Further, companies have an option in producing group accounts in deciding whether to produce a single set of consolidated accounts or separate accounts for each subsidiary. Even before the establishment of the new national scheme for corporate regulation on 1 January this year, the Attorney-General, Mr Michael Duffy, had publicly identified reforms to this area of the law as a priority for the new scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: I can now foreshadow-and it will be of interest to Senator Schacht-that the Government will be introducing, in its first amending legislation under the new national scheme, amendments to require companies to produce a consolidated set of accounts covering all the companies and other entities that they control, including providing a broad definition of control. This directly tackles the use of off balance sheet vehicles like trusts and partnerships. It also does away with the option that holding companies have had until now about whether they consolidate the accounts of the companies in their group. Consolidation will now be compulsory.

Amendments will permit the effective operation of an accounting standard on this issue which was approved by the Accounting Standards Review Board in the late 1990s and which I understand was the subject of the discussions between the Attorney-General and the chairman of the Accounting Standards Review Board. So I believe that between the profession of accountancy and the national Parliament-under the new regulation framework provided for companies and securities throughout Australia-we will be able to provide a remedy for the situation that Senator Schacht has described.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that the war against Iraq killed-and estimates vary-between 40,000 and 250,000 Iraqis; given that food shortages, infrastructure collapse and civil violence will cause tens of thousands more deaths in the coming months and dire pre-industrial poverty for decades; given that more than one million Kurds and Shi'ites have fled their homes in Iraq and that Palestinians are being persecuted in Kuwait; given that the oil spills and well fires are environmental disasters which are causing profound health problems in the region; and given that the so-called new world order holds little promise of justice for the Kurds, Palestinians, East Timorese, Tibetans and Cypriots, does the Government still believe that the decision to go to war was correct?
—Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his statement as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday, 13 April. The article quoted the Minister as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The existing tax rules did not provide any favourable treatment for unions or any other political donors.
Does the Minister stand by his statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I stick to the point I was making at the press conference last Friday. If trade union organisations are compared to corporate sector representative bodies, my understanding is that they are treated in the same way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In light of concerns expressed last week about the future of Australia's telecommunications manufacturing industry, can the Minister indicate what sort of role Telecom Australia might play in the continuing development of the Australian telecommunications industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of ongoing discussion as the telecommunications industry evolves. Both Telecom and OTC Ltd have been important agents for the growth of the local telecommunications industry as they purchase an estimated $2.6 billion worth of equipment in the equipment market. Local content in this equipment can be as high as 70 per cent in the case of small earth stations and optical fibre submarine and transmission equipment. Under such schemes as the offsets program, partnerships for development and the industry development arrangements, local suppliers-both Australian and overseas owned-have built a world competitive manufacturing base, with exports of nearly $200m in 1989-90. The introduction of a second carrier will provide greater opportunities for the equipment suppliers. As part of the process of selecting a second carrier, the Government will require prospective carriers to outline their industry development proposals which might include measures such as local sourcing, local research and development, local investment, and the export of local goods and services.

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom will also be required to continue to play its part in industry development measures. Given the competitiveness of the equipment supplier industry and Australia's acknowledged leading role in telecommunications technologies, I can see little need for Telecom to change its level of local industry support. We would therefore expect Telecom to continue to play a major part in the development of a stronger local telecommunications industry. Senator Kernot asked Senator Collins a question about a similar matter last week. This comes to me as industry Minister, and I am just fleshing out some of the points that Senator Collins made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the Minister's response to an earlier question from Senator Tambling, can he say whether trade union dues are tax deductible and whether trade union affiliation fees to the Australian Labor Party are paid from tax deductible moneys?

—I can say that trade union and employer associations are, I am advised, exempt from income tax by specific provision of the law. Political parties are not exempt, but member subscriptions and voluntary donations would not be income for taxation purposes, and periodical subscriptions by members of trade unions and employer organisations generally are deductible. Voluntary donations to political parties are not considered to relate to the derivation of assessable income by individual donors and are not deductible. Special levies or contributions by members of trade unions or employer organisations to assist a political party are not deductible as they do not relate to the derivation of assessable income by members. I return to the basic point: the trade union and employer associations are exempt from income tax by specific provisions of the law.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is inaudible. By his mumbling and reading from a text, he is not able to communicate an answer to the Senate. I believe that he should start his answer again and in future speak in a clear voice on matters about which he purports to have some understanding.
—There is no point of order. It is not a matter that I am in control of. I call Senator Bolkus.
—I have completed my answer, Mr President.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With all goodwill, I tell Senator Bolkus that it is very difficult to hear him on this side of the chamber. We find it extremely difficult. However, I ask the Minister whether trade unions are exempt from income tax and whether trade unions are exempt from capital gains tax.
—I am sorry that Senator Walters could not hear but I have already answered those two questions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of Senator Hill's criticism over the weekend that the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) process has not lived up to the expectations created for it by the Government and is not making any progress in dealing with the issues of regional economic concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment APEC is going more or less exactly as planned and hoped. Senator Hill's comments about it over the weekend show that he either does not understand the concept, does not understand anything about diplomacy in the Asia-Pacific region, or that he does understand all of that but simply cannot forbear from making silly, partisan, political point-scoring comments because he cannot stand seeing Australia have any diplomatic success under this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make four points as quickly as I can about APEC's progress. In the first place, since November 1989, 10 major work projects have been set in train, on nearly all of which substantial progress is expected to be reported at the forthcoming ministerial level meeting in Seoul in October. Those projects deal with the following subjects: review of trade and investment data; trade promotion programs and mechanisms; investments and technology transfer; human resource development; regional energy cooperation; marine resource conservation; telecommunications; fisheries; transportation; and tourism. I am not suggesting that the results in the short term will be spectacular under any one of those heads. It would be a complete misunderstanding of the nature of the work that is in progress to expect that. But I have every reason to believe that progress under each of those areas will be both steady and constructive.

Secondly, while the APEC group has voiced very strong support for the principles of the Uruguay Round-and most APEC members are, of course, key players in the Uruguay Round in their own right-it was anticipated from the outset that its major trade liberalisation activity as a group would have a post-Uruguay focus. With this in mind, at Australia's initiative there has now been set in train at a recent officials' meeting a major exercise in examining the scope for non-discriminatory regional trade liberalisation. Again, movement on an issue as complex and delicate as that can hardly be fast, but it does have the potential over time to contribute immense benefits and very important momentum to international trade liberalisation objectives.

Thirdly, the participation in APEC by the three Chinese economies of the People's Republic of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong is the subject right now of active discussion and negotiation. The hope still is that that issue will be able to be resolved in favour of the admission of those three economies at the Seoul meeting. That was always the timetable. All the issues involved in that exercise are hugely complex, given the political dynamics in the region. We simply do not solve these sorts of problems by `bull at a gate' political rhetoric of the kind that Senator Hill is advocating.

The final point I specifically make is that APEC itself has now firmly consolidated regional political support behind it, something which obviously could not be taken for granted, even in the aftermath of the inaugural conference in Canberra in November 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the trade bloc in Malaysia?

—I will tell honourable senators something about the Malaysian trade bloc. The Malaysian proposal for an east Asia economic grouping is now being looked at from all sides in terms of how it fits within or alongside APEC, rather than the converse. If Senator Hill does not understand the significance of that, he knows even less than I thought he did about the currents at work in the region.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me finally say this: I genuinely believe that Australia's interests are best served by a bipartisan approach in external affairs issues so far as that is humanly possible. I do not mind, nor could anyone, honest differences of opinion or honest criticisms by the Opposition, but I do mind, here as elsewhere, pathetically unsupported and ill-judged attempts to talk down foreign policy initiatives which, if they are successful, are initiatives very much in the interest not of the Government but of Australia as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the Minister's response to questions earlier from Senator Tambling and Senator Walters, will he confirm that all donations, with the minor exception of special levies, from trade unions to the Australian Labor Party are paid from tax free money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that this line of questioning should develop today in that we are now being exposed to the real story behind the press statement of the Liberal Party of Australia last week on disclosure. It was accepted by a number of commentators that Dr Hewson may have won a victory in his party room on disclosure. The press statement that came out reflected that victory. I made the point at the time that the press statement was loaded with a number of qualifications which, in time, would develop and lead to a situation where the Liberal Party would not support the Government's full disclosure provisions. Having said that, I also pointed to the fact that Mr Robb and Mr Goldsworthy, the operatives of the Liberal Party organisation, on the same day as the Liberal Leader's statement on disclosure, remained unconvinced that government--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I asked the Minister a simple question: is it true that all donations, with the minor exception of special levies, from trade unions to the Labor Party are paid from tax free money? He is skirting around the subject. I ask you to ask the Minister to answer the question.
—I believe that Senator Bolkus is developing an argument and that he will answer the question.

—Mr President, I am glad that you have confidence in me. As I said, at the same time as Dr Hewson put out his statement, the Liberal Party organisation said that it remained to be convinced that the Government was able to meet its requirements of fairness and equity. It was a qualified statement; it was contradicted at the time of its release. The basic point is that the Liberal Party has raised a number of qualifications which position it in a manner-

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Alston had remained seated, I would have answered the question by now.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is very important that we get direct answers to questions. You have ruled time and again that Ministers should not debate the question. We have here now a deliberate attempt to talk about everything but the right answer. If the Minister refuses to answer, let him say so, but let him not waste everyone's time with this deliberate tactic.

—On the point of order: the question asked by Senator Parer has all sorts of prejudices and assumptions in it. He has not explained to this chamber what his definition of `tax free' is. We cannot expect Ministers to answer loaded questions in which no-one knows the definition of what one is talking about. Therefore, Senator Bolkus does require some latitude in answering the question to put it into some sort of context. If he answers Senator Parer's simple question with all the assumptions in it, there will be an inaccurate answer because neither side of the chamber will agree on the definitions.

—Mr President, on that point of order: on a number of occasions you have ruled upholding the original ruling of Sir Magnus Cormack that if a Minister chooses to answer the question-which he may not necessarily do-he is required to direct his remarks to that question and that question only. In line with your own precedent, Mr President, I would ask you to rule again in that way.

—Order, Senator Bishop! I am not breaking that precedent. I think Senator Bolkus is allowed some time to develop an argument. By his own admission, he was about to finish his answer. I call Senator Bolkus.

—Thank you, Mr President. I go to the point in issue. The basic response, as I have said already I think twice today in Question Time, is that trade union and employer associations are exempt from income tax by specific provisions of the law. That is the basic point. That provides the equity and the level playing field in the area and that is the specific response to Senator Parer's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say in closing that what has happened today is that the cat has been let out of the bag and Dr Hewson's principal position of last week is looking pretty thin.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's response at last that the Labor Party does receive favourable treatment because all union donations and affiliation fees are tax free-whereas donations by individuals or companies to political parties, whether it be the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats, are after-tax money and non-deductible-does he still stand by his statement that `existing tax rules did not provide any favourable treatment for unions or any other political donors'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that I stand by my statement and there is no doubt that trade union organisations and employer associations are treated in the same way. I must also say to Senator Parer and to the Senate that political parties are treated equally under our tax laws as well. Do not use those excuses to squirm out of the Opposition Leader's commitment last week on disclosure. Disclosure means that. Disclosure means a fair and open relationship between political parties in this process and the electorate. There is nothing to be qualified about that.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said last week, our disclosure proposals are extremely well known. This is but one escape clause that the Opposition Leader has allowed for himself. He knows that he will step back from his commitment. We know he will do it. The fraud is on the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that many of the little batteries that drive our watches, calculators, alarm clocks and more are actually mercury batteries? Would he agree that there are huge numbers of these batteries, not only in use but also expired, and that these are mostly disposed of through ordinary garbage to standard garbage sites? Would he agree that this is a matter of concern, particularly over time as the number accumulate? Would the Minister look at ways in which this toxic waste could be targeted for special collection and even possible recycling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that most of the small batteries do contain some quantities of mercury and that when those batteries are discarded they will mostly finish up in a land fill of some form around Australia. I have to say that that is not highly desirable but it is probably the most effective form of containing the damage that that mercury can do, provided that the land fill is the right kind. Studies in Australia and overseas have shown that disposal to controlled land fill is still the best way.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem overseas is that in countries such as Japan waste disposal is done by means of incineration. That can be quite dangerous with mercury batteries. The truth is that rather than looking for a better way of disposing of these batteries-and the Government is committed to a proper national strategy on waste minimisation and recycling-we might be better off getting a better product in the first place. I would hope that efforts can be made to look at successful battery recycling for certain, but also looking at batteries which do not require mercury in the first place. If we can have a combination of controlled land fill now and a proper waste minimisation strategy and recycling, we can do something about products that do not contain mercury at all, and the world would be a better place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, and relates to the $7.6m missing from the Ravenshoe sawmill. I ask the Minister whether the Government has received any reports from the receivers under section 324C of the Companies Code or section 422 of the corporations law in relation to the mill and whether the receivers indicated in these reports the possibility that the directors may have breached the law in their management of the company or incurred debts at a time when the company was insolvent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 422 of the corporations law to which Senator Boswell referred substantially covers the duty of company receivers to do two things: first, to lodge a report with the Supreme Court where it appears that company officers may have committed an offence and, secondly, to provide the Australian Securities Commission with such information as it requires. Section 324C of the Companies Code, as I understand it, is substantially the same. It is apparent, therefore, that the receivers are not required to report to either the Minister or the Department on this matter. The receivers were appointed by the Westpac Banking Corporation, not by the Commonwealth. Therefore, questions on how its receivership is proceeding would be best directed to that corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand the reason for the question which is, of course, a concern for some of the companies which are creditors of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd in Ravenshoe itself. I will endeavour to find out from the Attorney-General what the timetable might be for the release of the kind of information Senator Boswell seeks. I am advised, since this matter was raised with me, that the construction of those sections means that it is a question of provision of reports to the Supreme Court and the Australian Securities Commission, not to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister may remember that on 19 September last year at an Estimates committee meeting he told me that my concerns must eventually be answered and should be answered. I ask him on this very important issue involving $7.6m which is missing whether he can give the Senate that information, whether it is in those reports or not, as the Government must be aware of the questions I have asked. Will he report back to the Senate urgently because there are people in north Queensland who are not being paid?

—I understand Senator Boswell's concern. I recall in round figures what I said to the Estimates committee, although I do not recall what I said word for word. I accept Senator Boswell's quotation. The problem is that I cannot reveal anything here from these reports-nor can the Attorney-General or the Minister, Mrs Kelly-which might affect possible Commonwealth action, be that action to do with matters that are criminal or with attempts to sue for recovery of moneys. My advice is that I cannot comment further or release information further because to do so might prejudice those actions. As I said, I understand the reason Senator Boswell is asking the question, and I shall try to get from the Attorney-General some sort of timetable so that the companies concerned might know what the future holds for them.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to reports of three studies published in the British Medical Journal that found that people who reduce their salt intake can lower their blood pressure even more than with drug treatment. Although individuals can choose not to add salt to food, their ability to do so in respect of processed foods is more limited. Could the Minister advise whether there are any plans in Australia to encourage manufacturers to lessen the amount of salt they put into processed foods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire points to one of many studies which support the use of dietary measures to control blood pressure. There is no doubt that sodium intake is an important factor in hypertension, though it is not the only factor. Many individuals with high blood pressure-some 40 per cent, I am told-do not respond to dietary salt reduction, just as some individuals who consume considerable amounts of salt do not have high blood pressure. The importance of encouraging people to quit smoking, for example, cannot be underestimated.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, the Government recognises the importance of salt as a factor in hypertension, as well as in stroke and heart disease. This is reflected in the Australian dietary guidelines as well as in Government support for community education initiatives to this end. In fact, one such initiative is being undertaken in Tasmania, in its community education program called the salt skip program, which promotes a healthy diet and emphasises lowering of salt intake.

As Senator Maguire suggested in his question, processed foods are a major source of salt in our diets and reducing the amount of salt in processed foods is to be encouraged. One approach already taken by the Government, I am advised by the Minister for Community Services and Health, is to establish under the better health program a food industry strategy task force whose aim is to foster communication and cooperation with the food industry in health promotion and consumer education, as well as the development of new products, such as low salt or no added salt processed foods, and the reduction of the salt content in existing products. In addition, the National Food Authority, which should commence operation on 1 July, will provide a forum for the Government to consult and communicate with the food industry.

That answer is from a brief provided by the Minister for Community Services and Health. But, of course, there is only so much that governments can do in regard to persons taking steps to reduce the possible incidence or the onset of various diseases. I believe that the choices that people make in the marketplace as to the goods they purchase, particularly food products, will in the end probably do more than regulations and penalties to ensure that they, as well informed consumers, purchase and eat the foods which will best promote their good health.

There is no greater penalty for businesses than losing a market share. If consumers insist on a range of choice, which includes salt reduced or salt free foods, I believe that that action in the marketplace will have a pronounced effect in ensuring that Australians eat healthier foods and, therefore, that many are in a position to reduce or control blood pressure and hypertension problems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Harrison inquiry into the meat industry-an inquiry which has important implications for all Australian States. Is the Minister aware of the editorial in the Herald-Sun last Thursday, 11 April 1991, headed `The Curran connection'? With regard to the Victorian Government's submission, the editorial said:

QUESTION.PARA: Certainly . . . it can be established beyond doubt that the Government bowed to union pressure to make amendments favourable to the union, it is a very serious matter.
Will this irresponsible behaviour of the Kirner Government in bowing to union pressure seriously jeopardise the value of the Harrison inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the remarks printed about the allegations concerning undue influence brought by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union on the Kirner Government but I understand that those allegations have been answered adequately and fully by the Premier of Victoria, Mrs Kirner, in scotching them in the State Parliament, I think, just last week.
—She has done no such thing.

—It may be that she has not done it to Senator Short's satisfaction, or indeed to the satisfaction of the editorial writer-whoever that person may be-of the Herald-Sun. But at least she has made it clear on the public record that the views presented by the Victorian Government are the Victorian Government's views.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think the Harrison inquiry is in any way a naive one. It is an inquiry by an experienced member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission bench who is well versed in the complex field of industrial issues in the meat industry. It is now a long running inquiry. I would have hoped that it would have reported before now, but I recognise its need to be thorough in its investigations in order to come to the best possible conclusions. Certainly, it will be well advised to be guided by the submission that the Commonwealth has made to that inquiry, because ours is indeed a thorough and full submission. But I recognise that all parties have put in good submissions. I hope that the inquiry can report shortly and provide a basis for reform in the meat industry because this is an area in which a reform of the industrial relations practices certainly needs to be brought about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the information that was left out of the Victorian submission was with regard to the figures on the costs of the disputes that have occurred in recent years, the time lost and the number of strikes, has the Federal Government included that data in its submission? If not, because of its importance to the final position that Commissioner Harrison will come to, will the Minister take steps to include that information or put it before the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question contains a premise in the form of an allegation that information that was to be put in was taken out of the Victorian submission. I think I have answered that as far as I am aware the Victorian Government-and this is the view of the Premier of the State-has indicated that the Victorian submission is the submission of the Victorian Government. The second part of this supplementary question asks about the Commonwealth's submission. We have put a very full submission before the Commission in order to lay before it all the relevant material. In the next day or so I have a proposal coming before me to add to our submission, in view of what else has been so far said on the record, in order to go into the greater detail that we think is necessary to provide the Commission with a basis for its decision.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of those things which Senator Crane has said were left out of the Victorian submission-which I do not in any sense confirm; I am certainly not in a position to do that-are certainly important questions in that Commission's arriving at a conclusion on this matter. I think we have adequately covered that field in what we have already said, but I will keep Senator Crane's remarks in mind when I look at what our supplementary submission should be. That will guide me in framing our final submission to the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. It relates to the deeming exemptions register which was to be established by the Department of Social Security to enable organisations to be approved by the Minister so that people wishing to make low interest or no interest loans to voluntary and charitable organisations could gain an exemption from the deeming provisions. I ask the Minister, firstly, how many applications the Government has received from organisations to be registered for approval and placed on the register. Secondly, how many applications for exemption has the Minister approved? Thirdly, in the interim, is interest of 10 per cent being deemed on the funds held with organisations which have applied to achieve status on the deeming register but which may not yet have been granted that status?

REGIONAL ECONOMIC COOPERATION:
WHITHER APEC?
AN ADDRESS BY SENATOR ROBERT HILL, SHADOW MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS, TO THE NORTH QUEENSLAND ZONE CONFERENCE OF THE LIBERAL PARTY
CAIRNS
13 APRIL 1991

I want to address the issue of regional economic relations and the importance of regional economic cooperation to Australia. In Queensland, as in the rest of Australia, we are feeling the bite of recession, a recession that can only be overcome by greater trade liberalisation and domestic reform. Australia needs to improve its competitive position, which requires not only significant internal structural adjustment, but a commitment to greater integration into the global and regional economies.

Much has been happening to influence global economic relations over the last few months, and these events have had, and will continue to have, an impact on Australia's trading position and economic wellbeing. In the post-Gulf War situation, the economic realm will come in for greater focus as economic security becomes fundamental to the security of a state.

For Australia, this means several things. It means firstly that a commitment to a multilateral trading regime, such as the GATT, is essential as structural change continues in the world economy. This process of globalism requires management of international economic relations through an international rule based regime with the objective of furthering world trade liberalisation.

In a period of great change, such as the one we are experiencing at the moment, there is a temptation to adopt discriminatory and protectionist economic policies in order to attempt to reassert control over the direction of national economies. This must be discouraged as it has detrimental effects for those not part of such agreements, and eventually the parties to such arrangements suffer, at the very least in terms of the economic efficiency of their production and practices.

The apparent breakdown of the Uruguay Round of the GATT talks in December 1990 and the restarting of them in February this year, is illustrative of this trend in the global economy. Member countries have been attempting to negotiate a new multilateral trading regime including areas not previously covered by the GATT, such as agriculture, services and intellectual property rights. Australia has been a player in these talks, through the Cairns Group of Agricultural Fair Trading Nations. However, it is over this very issue-agriculture-that the talks have stalled.

The intransigence of the European Community (EC), Japan and South Korea over the protection of their agricultural markets has meant that very little progress in all areas has been made. Agriculture has been the key to the negotiations, with progress on this directly related to the preparedness of developing countries to make concessions with regard to the concerns of the more developed countries in areas such as intellectual property rights.

Yet whilst the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round must remain one of Australia's highest economic priorities, attention must also be given to our Asia-Pacific region and the opportunity for greater economic integration within it. Our future lies in this region and we must attempt to play an active and appropriate role.

Australia has always been an enthusiastic initiator and supporter of regional economic arrangements, often in tandem with Japan. Australia was instrumental in the formation of the Pacific Basin Economic Committee (PBEC), a private organisation of business interests which originated from Australia-Japan business cooperation. In 1980, a seminar prompted by discussions between Prime Minister Fraser and Japan's Prime Minister Ohira then resulted in the establishment of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference (PECC) in 1982. PECC brings together in an informal manner a combination of representatives from government, business and the academic world which has been significant in encouraging greater economic cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region.

More recently, there has been the establishment of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in 1989 as a result of an Australian initiative. Prime Minister Hawke and Senator Evans have claimed it as possibly their finest foreign policy achievement. Not surprisingly, as the Coalition was intimately involved in the development of economic cooperation in the region over the past few decades, we also welcomed APEC. We recognised its potential-potential clearly still present. Yet it is not too early to assess whether that potential is being realised. It is on the progress of APEC that I now wish to dwell.
APEC[1] is designed as a ministerial-level forum to pursue three general objectives for regional economic cooperation[2] which include:
(i) greater regional coordination of economic activities and policies, including various practical projects;
(ii) communication and exchange of information on trade and investment flows, including the establishment of regional information bases; and
(iii) attempts to jointly advance multilateral trade liberalisation, and to respond to the limits of multilateral regimes for the region.

As the third annual ministerial meeting approaches[3], there are regrettably very few positive achievements that can yet be identified. Perhaps in part it relates to the style in which these objectives are pursued. APEC has from the start been very much an informal consensus building forum, designed to be sensitive to the heterogeneity in culture, ethnic composition, ideology, security interests and levels of economic development of the AsiaPacific region. Whilst this is in essence the most productive way for a region with such diversity as this to cooperate, it must not become an excuse for inaction.

The first APEC meeting, held in Canberra in 1989, was claimed to be significant singly because it was held at all. A government-level forum to deal with the economic concerns of the region was unprecedented, with the main area of agreement arising from this meeting being cooperation with respect to the furtherance of the Uruguay Round.

The second APEC meeting, held in Singapore in 1990, reviewed progress in work projects, focused on APEC's commitment to the Uruguay Round and confirmed the desirability of the participation of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. However little else originated from this meeting apart from reiterating previously determined objectives.

Without real progress on the crucial economic issues facing the region, APEC risks being dismissed simply as yet another talk-shop. It is important for APEC to start to show evidence of progress on difficult regional economic concerns and it is now an appropriate time to concentrate on this.

Where is the evidence of greater regional coordination of economic activities and policies, the first general objective which has been identified? Work projects have indeed been established including the review of trade and investment data, trade promotion, expansion of investment and technology transfer, human resources development, energy cooperation and marine resource cooperation. But yet these projects have produced little in the way of concrete results and little that could not have been done by existing regional organisations such as the PECC.

The second general objective, that of communication and exchange of information has fared little better. There has been a great deal of dialogue, at the ministerial and officials level, which no doubt is useful, but in practical terms it has taken until now to reach agreement on a proposal by Singapore to establish a trial regional electronic trade and economics data bank[4]. The establishment of regional information bases of standardised data should be a priority goal.

The third general objective, that of cooperation with respect to furthering the Uruguay Round, has been hailed as evidence of APEC's success. Yet the Uruguay Round stalled in December 1990 largely as a result of the intransigence of three parties, two of which are participants in APEC-Japan and South Korea. Although there are indications that if the EC made concessions with respect to agriculture, the other two may be persuaded to as well, at present all three are unwilling to come out from behind their protectionist trade barriers.

APEC has been of limited use in helping to resolve this. APEC aimed at adopting a common position with respect to these GATT negotiations, but despite the successful rhetoric of cooperation and the image of a united front, little in reality has been achieved in this respect. Yet APEC retains the commitment, reiterated at the most recent APEC Senior Officials Meeting in South Korea in early March, to the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round as its top priority.

In addition, a commitment to further the Uruguay Round sits uneasily with the lack of regional commitment to trade liberalisation and trade openness. Almost all APEC participants have significant levels of protection in some sectors. For example, contrasted with the efficient agricultural production of Australia and New Zealand is the protection evidenced in the agricultural sectors of not only Japan and South Korea, but some ASEAN countries and Taiwan. In addition, protection is high in the manufacturing industries of Australia, New Zealand, the United States and Canada. This contrasts with Singapore and Hong Kong, which have the most liberal import systems in the world.

Indeed, APEC has only recently agreed that general regional trade liberalisation is an appropriate area for further detailed study and consideration[5]. This is in response to an Australian discussion paper on non-discriminatory trade liberalisation in the region. It is unfortunate that it has taken Australia, or any other regional country for that matter, so long to circulate a paper on such a crucial topic. Although the preferred approach of the region has always been a process of consensus-building, and indeed APEC is considering liberalisation in specific areas, it really does seem that regional trade liberalisation as a whole should have been on the agenda in a much more defined way from the very beginning of APEC. The question of regional structural adjustment is perhaps the most important one for APEC but the one to which the least amount of attention has been paid.

Trade liberalisation is assuming increased importance in response to very definite signs from within the region of an exploration of greater discrimination in trading policies. The apparent breakdown of the Uruguay Round triggered all sorts of propositions, including one from the Australian Prime Minister to consider using APEC as the basis of an Asian trading bloc should the GATT Round fail completely. This suggestion must be dismissed as totally counter-productive for the region, indeed many of APEC's participants are committed to APEC precisely because it was not intended as a regional bloc.

There is no doubt that certain global trade signals indicate the move towards more defined regional trading blocs. It is still too early to say however, whether European market integration in 1992 will result in the feared ``Fortress Europe'' outcome. In turn, the agreement by the US, Canada and Mexico to negotiate a North American Free Trade Agreement, as an expansion of the existing United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement, has led to justifiable fears about the maintenance of market access. The announcement by Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay of the creation of the Southern Common Market Treaty (Mercosur) to aim at free trade between the four countries is also indicative of this trend.

However, proposals for Asia-Pacific regional trading blocs are not a useful response to these indications. Malaysia's proposal for an East Asian Economic Group (EAEG) in December 1990 appeared to aim at the formation of an inward looking trading bloc: to include the ASEAN nations, Japan, South Korea, China, Hong Kong, Burma and Indochina; but excluding the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

This call seemed not only designed as a response to the global devolution towards trading blocs, but as a response to developing countries' concerns that they were being excluded by developed nations. If this indeed is the case, then APEC is failing in its attempt to bring the countries of the region together in a manner which enables equal exchange of views. Perhaps there is a perception that the developed nations are dominating APEC which could help explain why Malaysia found it necessary to make such a proposal.

It is encouraging to note that Malaysia has since moved away from the trade bloc idea, although it is still not entirely clear as to just what is being proposed. It is also encouraging to note that two potential members, Japan and Indonesia, have rejected the idea, with China giving a fairly cautious response. It is more surprising however for Singapore, a model of openness, to be expressing support.

What also needs to be cautioned against in APEC is a domination of APEC's agenda by the United States-Japan trade friction. This is likely to assume a greater importance as the two experience disputes over areas such as semiconductors, construction, Japan's role in the Uruguay Round, the Structural Impediments talks and Japan's financial contribution to the Gulf War.

These disputes will inevitably affect the countries of the Asia-Pacific region as the US and Japan dominate so much of regional trade. Both are the major trading partners of most in the region and therefore market access becomes an issue, with fears of greater protection in the US or managed bilateral trade if disputes are not resolved. Depending on how these disputes are managed, it is possible that APEC will spend increasing amounts of time trying to deal with issues arising from the differences between the two.

In addition, apart from not meeting its claimed objectives, there is still the question of APEC's inadequate membership. A body to reform economic relations in the region will exist in a world of unreality if it does not include China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Yet so far APEC has been unable to find criteria for eligibility and a way of allowing the political sensitivities of China to be accommodated.

China, Taiwan and Hong Kong are all distinct economies which should be included in APEC as a matter of priority due to their economic importance to the Asia-Pacific region. Indeed, the inclusion of Hong Kong should never have been a real problem as it has not yet reverted to Chinese control, is a member of the GATT and an exemplary free trader.

With adequate resolve it should be possible to find a formula, perhaps the Asian Development Bank or PECC model where the issues of names was resolved and both regarded as ``economies'' and not countries. One therefore questions whether the resolve is present.

There is also the question of APEC's relationship with other countries of the region. Participating states have not worked out a formula for linkage with the Soviet Union and the Pacific states of Latin America despite being pressed to do so.

Indeed the region needs to decide how the Soviet Union is relevant and engage it in some form of greater interaction. This might avoid proposals such as one rumoured that President Gorbachev is expected to propose a Japan Sea economic bloc, incorporating China, North and South Korea, Japan and the Soviet Union. The combination of technology from Japan and South Korea, Soviet resources and Chinese labour may well be tempting, but the region generally would suffer with such an inward looking arrangement[6].

However, even resolving questions of participation, one must question the effective usefulness of APEC whilst there is no satisfactory interface with business. From the outset business was not included which struck the Coalition as a fundamental flaw. Business interests need to have an input into APEC's working groups and representation, perhaps through observer status, at APEC meetings. Economic development cannot be examined in isolation from commercial realities. Regional economic cooperation is not just about changing government policy, at the commercial level it will be business interests that determine the success or failure of such policies.

APEC must produce concrete results. Dialogue and exchange of views at a government level is always useful but more must be achieved. The more practical outcomes: the changes in government policy, the alteration of business practices, the communication of information to improve economic performance, have to be the priority. By achieving positive outcomes dialogue and cooperation will be reinforced. Without practical results APEC will become a disinterested forum incapable of real progress on regional issues.

Regional issues must become APEC's primary focus. It will be too easy to focus on multilateral causes, such as the GATT, and although attention should indeed be paid to this, there are already appropriate multilateral forums in which to do this. By contrast, there are a limited number of regional forums designed specifically to cope with regional economic cooperation and structural adjustment. APEC must not become distracted from regional issues.

It is time for governments to take a hard look at APEC and its objectives. It is time to evaluate whether useful outcomes are being achieved and whether there is room for greater productive interaction. Consensus building is a slow process but it must not be used as an excuse for lack of progress. With a firm commitment to regional economic cooperation, APEC has the potential to not only liberalise trade, but to play a useful role in the resolution of regional differences and help carry the region through a difficult time into the twenty-first century.
[1] APEC participation comprises Australia, Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Republic of Korea, Singapore, Thailand and the United States.
[2] See Jenelle Bonnor (1990) The Politics of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, Masters Thesis, Australian National University, Canberra.

[3] The third APEC Ministerial-level meeting is to held in Seoul, South Korea in October 1991. It is also to be noted that the APEC Ministerial- level meetings are supported by more regular Officials meetings.
[4] APEC Senior Officials Meeting, Cheju, South Korea, 6 March 1991.
[5] APEC Senior Officials Meeting, Cheju, South Korea, 6 March 1991.
[6] Steve Burrell ``Gorbachev to push USSR-Japan bloc'', Australian Financial Review, 8 March 1991.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1991, to incorporate into that Act a proposal to increase the duty on exported uranium concentrate, which was tabled in this Chamber by myself on 10 May 1990, and is effective from 21 February 1990, being the date of effect of that Proposal in accordance with section 273ea of the Customs Act 1901 (Clause 2).

The proposal, which increases the export duty on uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory Region from $1.15 to $1.30 as from 21 February 1990, is incorporated in Clause 3 of the Bill.

Clause 4 of the Bill provides an exemption from the increased levy where uranium concentrate was loaded on to a vessel, or was part of a consignment, the loading of which was commenced prior to the 21 February 1990 commencement of the Bill.

The levy, which applies only to exports of uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory, is imposed to partially offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities undertaken by the Commonwealth to protect the Alligator Rivers Region. The increase in the level of the levy reflects the Government's position that the costs associated with protecting the environment from the potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne as far as is practicable by the industry carrying out those operations, and not the ordinary taxpayer.

Successive Governments throughout the 1980's have recognised that the Alligator Rivers Region, which includes Kakadu National Park, requires special measures to ensure that its sensitive environment receives adequate protection from the possible adverse effects of uranium mining.

The significance of the Alligator Rivers Region should not be underestimated-large parts of the Area have received international recognition by being placed on the world heritage list. Australia has specific obligations under the World Heritage Convention to ensure such areas are not degraded.

The Commonwealth's contribution to the protection of the Alligator Rivers Region is through the operation and research undertaken by the Office of the Supervising Scientist and other Commonwealth Agencies, in addition to the provision of funds for services by agencies of the Northern Territory Government on behalf of the Commonwealth.
The services provided by the Northern Territory on behalf of the Commonwealth include:
* the application of National codes of practice relevant to nuclear materials,
* safety, health and mining regulations and
* environmental monitoring.
The costs of these services are offset by contributions from the Commonwealth in the annual revenue grant to the Northern Territory Government.

The programs and role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (``OSS'') have been reviewed and endorsed on a number of occasions. The most recent review, the Taylor review, concluded in November 1989 that the OSS is as necessary today as it was in 1978, (when it was established), as the community continues to require assurances from an independent and competent source that the environment of the region is being protected from the adverse effects of mining.

The uranium export duty, which only applies to the export of uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers Region, was introduced by the Coalition Government in 1980. The increases in the duty that have occurred since 1980 reflect the Government's position that those involved in uranium mining activities in the Alligator Rivers Region, and not the ordinary taxpayer, should incur as far as possible, the costs associated with protecting that environment from possible adverse effects arising from their activities.

The proposed increase in duty from $1.15 to $1.30/kg from 21 February 1990 has been implemented in an effort to move towards full cost recovery of the Government's environment protection measures associated with mining in the Alligator Rivers Region.

The Government makes no apology for its policy of supporting full cost recovery of all Government expenditure used in protecting the environment from uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region. However, it recognises that limitations exist in the present export duty system which, for example, requires an amendment to legislation whenever a change to the amount of revenue required is needed. Further, it notes that the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts report on The Potential of the Kakadu National Park Region and the Taylor Review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist suggested that the levy could be applied more equitably as organisations other than uranium mining companies either utilise or benefit from the results of OSS research. The Government will be addressing these issues and examining alternative means for collecting these costs in a more effective and equitable manner.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed increased duty raised an additional $0.222 million during 1989/90 and is expected to raise an additional $0.932 million over the full 1990/91 financial year.

In the 1989/90 financial year the levy raised $4.007 million. Between July and February of the 1990/91 financial year $6.146 million has been raised by the levy, and based on current projected exports it is expected that a further $1.066 million will be raised during the March-June period, giving an estimated total amount to be raised during the 1990/91 financial year of $7.212 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1991SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991
