SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1991 and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 was interrupted when matters of public interest were called on last Thursday. At that stage, I had made the point that I welcomed the Government's change of attitude on the so-called luxury tax on higher priced vehicles. The Government has reverted to the old system under which the rate was 20 per cent and then 30 per cent on the retail price of vehicles of $45,000. This is certainly a backdown by the Government on the decision that it made on the run to impose a sales tax of 50 per cent on so-called luxury vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out that when this amending legislation becomes law there will still be a differential of 10 per cent in respect of vehicles priced over $45,000 retail. Anything under that will be 20 per cent and anything over will be 30 per cent. So this differential of 10 per cent will still be aimed at the higher priced vehicle which could be considered a luxury vehicle. Unfortunately, once again, this legislation takes in vehicles which, for certain reasons, may be in the heavier class. Heavier vehicles are needed in certain areas-for instance, remote areas-for safety reasons. In other words, I believe that there will be an extra 10 per cent sales tax on safety.

When one is driving a lighter vehicle around a city, one is limited in most cases to a speed limit of 60 kilometres an hour. If one has an accident with another car or if one hits a tree, one has a much greater chance of surviving than one would have if one had an accident in areas where the speed limit was 110 kilometres an hour, which is the average open road speed in Australia.

I have seen the results of such accidents. Unfortunately, in only the last 12 months I know of two accidents in which a lighter vehicle has hit a tree, with tragic results. A person driving a heavier land cruiser type of vehicle would have some chance of coming out with his life intact. I believe that where these sorts of vehicles are registered in remote areas, the Government should look at removing this 10 per cent differential, which is to be imposed across the board. I believe that the Government has a long way to go in this respect.

I refer to a schedule put out by the Australian Taxation Office which relates to vehicles which are totally sales tax exempt. The schedule contains a lot of surprises in terms of the exemptions that are made. The main exempt vehicles are four-wheel drive vehicles with a one tonne carrying capacity used in the agricultural industry.

The agricultural industry is the main industry in which such vehicles, if they are used primarily and principally in that industry, are sales tax free. Other categories are the mining industry, ambulances, schools, organisations promoting the interests of schools, organisations promoting competitive sport among students of schools and universities, consular posts, Commonwealth or State government departments, the Reserve Bank of Australia, public transport authorities, local government and so on.

There are a few exceptions that I find peculiar, although that does not mean they should not be included. I wonder whether in these cases there are joint arrangements with other countries. It refers to members of the armed forces of the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand. I am wondering-and I shall probably ask questions about this in the Committee stage of the Bill-whether we have reciprocal arrangements with those other countries and, if not, why not, and why these arrangements do not apply to the armed forces of, say, other countries that are friendly with Australia? This seems somewhat peculiar.

I welcome a new ruling by the Australian Taxation Office last week. A four-wheel drive vehicle of one-tonne carrying capacity with seating for only two passengers was the norm for exemption of sales tax. Last week's ruling brought into line the dual cab type of four-wheel drive-in other words, vehicles that can carry five passengers as well as a load. That welcome ruling was sales tax ruling 2343. It is a ruling which those in the primary and in mining industries have been trying to get for a long time.

There is one industry missing from this schedule. I wonder why the fishing industry does not have the same exemptions. Fishing is classed as a primary industry and provides great foreign income for Australia, yet it does not seem to be given the same consideration as other primary industries.

We welcome the removal of the items of sales tax contained in this Bill. The Government has seen the folly of its ways in that it did not raise the $100m to be spent on those black spots on our roads. I understand that the $100m was made up from general budget items somewhere else, such as fuel taxes. The Government committed a great folly, and I suppose we must give the Government credit for seeing the error of its ways and backing down. Hopefully the Government will not make such promises on the run in future, but will think these things out before putting them into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating two related Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bills which result from the prime ministerial statement of 12 March and from a House of Representatives committee report brought down in 1990. The first of these reduces sales tax on luxury cars from 50 per cent to 30 per cent, and the second allows for quarterly rather than monthly payments of sales tax but with a liability below $50,000. Both measures have the support of the coalition. One rectifies an expensive mistake that was made last year, and the other is a small step in the right direction. At the same time this legislation illustrates the failure of the Hawke Labor Government to reform an illogical and unfair system of indirect taxation and a system that it wishes to misuse and manipulate.

SPEECH.PARA: The abandonment of the 1990 attempt to levy a new 50 per cent sales tax on cars retailing over $45,000 is nothing less than an admission of abject failure, even though we should not hold our breath for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to say that he got it wrong. The Treasurer gets it wrong more often than not but, of course, we never hear an admission from him. This attempt to raise an additional $105m through a deliberate appeal to the politics of envy and jealousy was the result of not a rational consideration but the desperation of an election campaign in which we saw a government do and say anything to get re-elected. That was not just apropos the last election but certainly all elections that this Hawke Labor Government has fought.

The legislation was also an example of taxation by press release, which we have seen throughout the eight long years of this Government. We do not get announcements made in the right and proper manner. We get them in a press release hidden somewhere for us to find, or we get announcements made in an answer to a dorothy dix question at Question Time. But are announcements made at the right place at the right time when they can quite rightfully get proper debate? No, they are not, and this is yet another example of that. It was an example of the worst possible kind, which could not be justified through the excuse by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that `such a method would be employed only to correct an abuse or deficiency of revenue laws'. Those words, I might add, were his, not mine.

Like all bad taxation legislation, the market has been distorted and otherwise efficient businesses have been damaged. With bankruptcies at the moment at unprecedented levels right throughout Australia, and particularly in my State of Western Australia, this Government does not seem to care one iota about the damage that its decisions are having not only on the businesses but also on the employees of those businesses.

Specialist retailers in luxury cars or more expensive cars were being sent to the wall and larger firms with other operations in Australia were suffering severe losses. But, once again, did the Government care? No, the Government did not; it simply saw that the initiative was not bringing in the tax that it thought it would; so it changed its mind. The mind change did not come about because of the damage that was being done to the industry or to the employment factor or to the number of businesses going broke; it was based purely on income.

It is estimated that this Bill will cost the Commonwealth $45m in revenue. Had the 50 per cent sales tax remained in place, the total cost to the taxpayer in lost revenue and the consequences of lost jobs would have been far greater. The oldest rule in the book, ignored of course by the Hawke Labor Government for political short term advantage, is that if a tax is increased disproportionately people will alter their purchasing and revenue will fall. That is exactly what happened after the introduction of this tax.

It is less than 12 months since this Parliament debated the original legislation imposing the 50 per cent rate, and the predictions of the Liberal-National Party coalition have been absolutely and utterly vindicated. We pointed out that this Government was ignoring the warnings of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industry and the Motor Traders Association; that, at best, the effect would be revenue neutral as the importation of luxury cars was already declining due to the effects of the recession-or the depression that `we had to have' according to Treasurer Keating-and that a further decline would cause a loss of tariff and sales tax revenue. We also made it clear that the effect of the tax rise applying in practice to imports was a de facto tariff increase that reduced competition in Australian car manufacturing and undermined the purported aim of the Government to fight for tariff reduction.

It is also significant to note that few members of the Government had the interest or the conviction to speak in support of legislation to honour a cheap election stunt and that the Australian Democrats, while voting for this disastrous Bill, were equally reluctant to argue the principle. But, of course, the Democrats' support for this Bill should surprise none of us because they will support anything that is a tax on envy, a tax on jealousy or a tax on anything that they believe they cannot have. The fact is that, in a lot of cases where people work hard, they should be allowed to do what they wish to do with their rewards without a tax on jealousy and envy.

One could not be all that critical if the Government acted unilaterally across the board in a fair and equitable way, but it does not do that. For example, we have a situation where, under the current system of taxation, clocks-bedroom clocks that are used by people who are lucky enough these days to have a job-are taxed at 30 per cent, but the tax on antique clocks is nothing. On the list goes-and I will come back to it later-of the many taxes being imposed in a very irrational and illogical way by this Government.

The failure of the attempt of the Hawke Labor Government to levy a punitive but workable rate of tax on luxury vehicles highlights two massive flaws in the system of wholesale sales tax. The first of these is the potential for manipulation for political theatre, and we have seen plenty of that over the last eight years. Tax rates can be increased to focus envy and at times resentment against the supposed purchasing habits of sections of our society without thought as to the practical consequences. It is the wealthier people in the society who pay more tax, yet this Government will seek irrationally to tax things to the point where, at the end of the day, people are disadvantaged even on the lower incomes.

Secondly, this sorry episode shows the inherent absurdity of politicians or civil servants trying to define a `luxury' for taxation at a higher rate. In this particular case the luxury tag had nothing at all to do with features on the motor vehicle. It had everything to do with the simple cost of that motor vehicle. It also had nothing to do with what the vehicle was going to be used for; it just had everything to do with envy. This legislation will still attempt to distinguish between luxury cars, now attracting a 30 per cent sales tax, and other vehicles that are taxed at 20 per cent. But the valid question remains that a Range Rover, for example, may be for some an affectation in St Georges Terrace but could represent a very logical investment for a farmer seeking long term value and safety for money. My colleague Senator Panizza has just touched on the very area of safety.

If the 30 per cent sales tax rate applies to luxuries, what are we to make of its continued application to television sets, radios, cameras and photographic equipment generally and, of course, the old faithful household clock? They are all taxed as luxuries, but we come to a situation where antique clocks are not. We also come to a situation where gold-plated bathroom fittings are not taxed at all but ordinary bathroom fittings, which each and every one of us use, are taxed. The whole thing is absolutely and utterly absurd.

This Government has increased sales tax during its term of office by over 206 per cent. What most people do not understand is how much sales tax they are paying on goods that they go and buy in the supermarket, or anywhere else for that matter. What most people think is that they have simply gone to a store and the shopkeeper has had the audacity to put a price up. In a lot of cases that is not the situation: the shopkeepers have reduced prices and reduced margins and therefore profitability, but what has gone up is the sales tax component.

I will give some examples. Flavoured milk and fruit juices used to be exempt, but they now attract a 10 per cent tax. Wines and ciders, also once exempt, now attract a 20 per cent tax. All the following items used to be exempt, but now attract a 20 per cent sales tax: low alcohol beer; household disinfectants; oils and lubricants for business; skin lotions and creams; and sun screens. Most people thought it was the manufacturers or shopkeepers who kept putting up the prices, but that was not so.

Of course, the taxpayer, in some circumstances, gets hit again because this Government-and I suppose quite rightly-has set about advertising campaigns to encourage people to use sun screens and buy lower alcohol drinks. But, of course, the taxpayer pays for those advertising campaigns. To make the taxpayer pay for them, the Government says, `We will increase the tax on low alcohol beer and we will increase the tax on sun screens from zero to 20 per cent'. We now have a situation in which all those increases have happened.

Since videotapes have become more and more popular, the Government has said, `There is another niche and another opportunity where we can increase tax'. The tax on videotapes has gone from 7 1/2 per cent to 30 per cent under this Government. The tax on compact discs, another popular friend of the young and not so young, has jumped 10 per cent from 20 per cent to 30 per cent.

How many people really realise what they are paying on the day-to-day goods? They are paying a 20 per cent sales tax for detergents, toilet paper, toilet soap, toothpaste, shampoo and children's toys. The tax on all those products has just gone up and up. It is not difficult to know and understand why tax under this Government has increased by 206 per cent.

Also, we are amongst the highest personally taxed people in the world; we just go on getting taxed more and more. This Government does not give a continental about taxing a kiddie's flavoured milk while keeping caviar and oysters exempt. It thinks that the current system is fair and equitable. I do not know of too many people who would think that that was fair and equitable. More average people in Australia would have an orange juice or a flavoured milk more often than they would a jar of caviar or a dozen oysters. But does the Government exempt the orange juice or flavoured milk? No; it just increases the taxes on them.

I have also mentioned a number of items in that little list that may not be strictly necessary to sustain life, but they are certainly goods that are purchased as a matter of course by most ordinary Australians. I am not trying to pick out products that everybody does not buy; I am trying to suggest that what we have in the discrepancy area of taxation at the moment are ordinary items that are purchased day in and day out.

Australia continues to endure an archaic system of indirect taxation that assumes that a range of household items is to be purchased only by the relatively affluent. That is the best way that I can describe how out of touch this Government is and, quite frankly, how out of touch, sadly, the Democrats are, because they always support additional taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler.
—It was only last year that Senator Spindler was in this place advocating a 60 per cent personal taxation level. That is quite correct and he cannot deny it.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, we have the politics of envy: people who have the temerity to go out and earn money should be taxed to death and have all incentive removed so that there is nothing remaining for them to spend at their discretion. No, give it all to Big Brother. That is what the Democrats and the Government are all about. The Democrats will reject any little piece of taxation legislation that has attached to it some benefit to some industry because they do not like it. They do not like anyone to be successful; they will put the brakes on any initiative that might see someone get a lucky break.

There continues to be no logical refuting of the coalition proposal for a goods and services tax. The Government admitted that back in 1984-85. Of course, the difference today is that it has its political master, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), saying, `You must not, and you will not, bring in a goods and services tax'.

The differences that we are looking at with a goods and services tax are that personal income tax will be reduced and there will not be the tax on exports that we currently endure at the rate of $1.2 billion in direct taxes. The $1.2 billion that is currently spent on taxes for all our exports, which goes to make us uncompetitive and creates additional problems with our balance of payments, will be abolished under our proposals. We will have one level of taxation for goods and services, not this archaic mishmash that we have at the moment. Under our proposal where, until recently, until the introduction of the Bill that we are debating today, there were five levels of taxation- 0, 10, 20, 30 and 50-there will be no such thing; there will be one level.

More importantly, Australians will also know when taxation for those goods and services is increased, unlike what Senator McMullan and his colleagues have done in the last eight years by increasing tax by 206 per cent underhandedly. Everyone will know when a goods and services tax is increased. Very few people have known when any tax has been increased under this Government, let alone to the tune of 206 per cent. If the Government can deny that, good luck to it. No-one out there understands what the Government has done; they think it is the shopkeepers.

As I have said, a goods and services tax will apply even-handedly. It will stop both politicians and the tax system from playing favourites and making archaic value judgments as to our free choice in purchasing what we want and can afford. As I have stated, it is a welcome step to allow businesses with a liability below $50,000 to pay sales tax quarterly. That is a good move. It is a start. It is about time. This, however, is merely a useful administrative reform. It is absolutely amazing-the Government has not made any tough decisions, and this one is just a child's first step in the right direction.

It does not alter the structure of sales tax which needs 11 separate Acts to govern its rates, and 14 Acts to govern its assessment, collection and administration. This is the Government which said, back in 1983, that it was going to make the tax system more simple and easier to understand. That is the biggest joke of all because, as I have said, we have 11 separate Acts to govern rates and 14 to govern assessment, collection and administration. If that is simple, I will go he.

It does not alter the fact that, despite some more foreshadowed window-dressing, the Government will continue to collect over $5 billion worth of sales tax from business inputs. If that does not make us uncompetitive, what does? Did the Government make any tough decisions on that in the non-existent industry statement of 12 March? No. There was hope that it might exempt business inputs-as the coalition plans to do-to make this country more competitive, but did the Government do that? No, it ran away from yet another tough decision.

The Business Council of Australia has pointed out that 49 per cent of sales tax is paid on the business purchase of intermediate inputs, with a further 14 per cent on the business purchase of investment goods. It does not alter the fact that sales tax costs exporters more than $1 billion-an effective average export tax of 2 per cent, rising to 4 per cent for forestry and wood products. It does not change the situation where compliance costs will continue to weigh heavily on smaller businesses that must bear the burden of collecting a tax, hidden from the consumer but paid, nonetheless.

Why must the Government continue to hide its grubby little taxes from the consumer? Why not have the courage to put it up front? Why not have the courage to reform in a proper manner? Why not have the courage to reform, full stop? No. It says, `We can't do that because the ACTU won't let us'. The situation will continue with 29 per cent of total sales tax payable on transport and transport equipment, and 24 per cent levied from household and office equipment and furniture.

That is not much of a level playing field, is it? The Government is great on talking about a level playing field. This is the bumpiest playing field that I have ever seen in my life! Having been in business but a few years ago, having experienced it in a practical sense and having sat in this Parliament for a number of years now, I can say that it is anything but a level playing field. This Government picks winners; it tries to decide who will benefit and who will not and, at the end of the day, we end up in a depression. That is good judgment, is it not?

The Hawke Labor Government, while it refuses to acknowledge the self-evident truth that the wholesale sales tax system is irredeemably unfair and distorting, can only tinker with yet another national problem that cries out for the rational solution that the coalition is determined to provide. It is about time that taxation became what the Government said it would become and has never delivered and that is, lower and more simple. We are advocating that. It is a shame, knowing that we are advocating it, that the Government has not taken up Dr Hewson's offer of bipartisan support for a number of tough tax decisions, but has kept on its belligerent downhill slide-which has been engineered by the ACTU-purely and simply because it wants to tax, and tax heavily.

I encourage the Government to think again, to think hard and to try to come up with a system where we can get back to it being worth people's time to work-for them to get rewarded for effort-and to stop us hearing all of the time people saying, `It is not worth my time to work overtime. I get taxed too heavily and, therefore, I will not work overtime'. We now have a situation where people cannot even get a job to work overtime. The tough decisions need to be made and I cannot see why they cannot be made now.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case some people are listening, I want to remind them, because they would not have gained any indication from recent speeches, that we are dealing with two Bills, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.1) 1991 and the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1991. SPEECH.PARA: There was some indication that perhaps the level at which the quarterly payment entitlement will cut in is too low. Some people have posed that question reasonably; others have indulged in absurd hyperbole about it and have tried to imply that somehow the drop in sales of luxury motor vehicles is in some way a product of the increase in tax. If that were true, as soon as the tax was changed back to its previous level, sales would leap up again to their former level. Nobody who is seriously addressing this question believes that that is likely to take place or that it is even remotely possible. How one determines the likely revenue outcome of any tax change is always a complex question, because we are required to make certain assumptions about people's behaviour in response to those changes.

Some calculations have been based on 1988-89 peak volume sales. I think that that is a highly unlikely basis upon which to make any current estimate or to have assumed that those sales would have continued had there been no tax. SPEECH.PARA: The most frustrating aspect of the debate about the wholesale sales tax versus the goods and services tax is the continuing failure of the Opposition to give details as to what it is they are going to do so that we can have a proper and informed debate about it. It is possible to argue that there are too many rates in the wholesale sales tax system at the moment and that some things have the wrong rates. All those things are legitimate grounds for public discussion about the relative merits of different types of tax. The fundamental flaw that I find in a goods and services tax that makes it so inequitable and leads to respected Australian groups concerned with social welfare to express their opposition to it is the fact that there is no zero rate-that is, everything that everybody buys is taxed; there are no exemptions.

SPEECH.PARA: We have all said in debates in this place in the past-and I do not want to repeat them-that there are merits in a goods and services tax, and of course there are, and there are shortcomings, and of course there are. —That is absolutely true.
—If that is the best you can put up--

—That was not the point of the question. The point of the question was the problem of the multitude of taxes that people in Australia pay at both Federal and State levels.

—I understand that Senator Watson was making several points about how hard some States make it for people to set up businesses. SPEECH.PARA: Even though it is a bit difficult to assess the relative position of that individual until the Opposition tells us what it is going to do about the goods and services tax, the one thing that is obvious is that for that individual to conduct his or her business-I think it was a male-he would have massively increased problems because of the need to impose a consumption tax on the service that he was providing. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

It is proper to disagree on that point because its conjecture indicates the difficulty in giving a very precise figure. DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1991STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on these two Bills, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill and the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill, gives the Senate a further opportunity to consider the Government's policies for Australian education. Those policies, I lament to the Senate, have caused disruption, confusion and uncertainty and have earned much criticism, not only from the Opposition but also from the public at large, especially from those in an informed position in education institutions and our universities, in our colleges and among students. I referred to these matters at some length on 12 March when the Senate debated the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill. I take up similar themes again in this debate because they are still relevant and are still not getting an adequate response from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills themselves do not in their specific provisions arouse great contention. They provide for the supplementation of Federal funding to higher education and to technical and further education (TAFE) in accordance with supplementation formulae. They are Bills that we regularly deal with at this time each year. The problem with them is not this particular supplementation, not the formulas, not the dollar amounts, but rather the whole financial and educational policy of this Labor Government which has generated the Bills and which is responsible for the failures in higher education and TAFE that we see.

A few other specific changes are made to higher education funding, such as the adjustments being made in Queensland by the removal of certain art and design courses from TAFE to higher education. One aspect that is not fully explained in the Minister's speech or in the explanatory memorandum is the reference to funding for the special overseas postgraduate fund. This is now to be spread over several years so that there can be a properly structured program. I ask the Minister at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), to provide some information about this and an explanation of what this means-whether there was not previously a properly structured program and when the program will be fully decided upon.

The wrong directions of this Government's higher education policies have been repeatedly made evident in the experience of our higher education institutions and in the public statements of people representative of those institutions and various faculties in direct criticism of the Government's record. In the light of this continuing evidence of the Government's failure, I move the Opposition's second reading amendment to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill in these terms:

At end of motion, add `, but the Senate deplores the Government's continued mismanagement of higher education, and, in particular, it deplores the Government's failure to provide the sector with the flexibility and incentives it needs to address the academic staff shortage, and to provide for adequate opportunities to meet the diverse educational needs of students'.

The amendment is restrained, it is brief, and pinpoints those matters that the Opposition has been directly concerned about in higher education. I expect that the Senate will be persuaded by the contributions to be made by a number of speakers on this side in this debate to adopt this amendment and so to bring home a message to the Australian Government on the need not to remain with its present record of failure. This is a cognate debate and we are also considering the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill. Later in my speech I will move on behalf of the Opposition a second reading amendment to that Bill. Similarly, I expect that to be persuasive in the Senate and to gain a clear majority of support. We will come to that in due course.

I say to all senators that the hallmark of the Dawkins approach has been to maximise governmental and bureaucratic influence in educational decision-making. We see this in the backroom pressures involved in the requirements for educational profiles, the burdens that these place on institutional administrations, and the intrusiveness into decisions that should be left to the institutions themselves to determine without this centralist Government's interference. All those accusations are real and we have been pointing them out before the White Paper that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) brought down. We regard it as centralist, as making for Government pressure in the backroom on institutions to comply with the Government's goals and determinations, and we object to it.

We believe that in the past three or four years in particular-and into the future-there should have been in Australia more autonomy in our higher education institutions without this centralist intrusion, interference, from Canberra. We see the Dawkins approach in the destruction of the previous system of independent advice to government. Here I am referring to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC), which this Government abolished. It had an outstanding record of giving advice on behalf of higher education throughout Australia not only to this present Labor Government but also to the preceding Liberal Government. In its place, Mr Dawkins has arranged things so that there is a National Board of Employment, Education and Training, which has nothing like the independence that CTEC had.

So whilst we have this record of failure, these continuing complaints being made about the conduct of higher education in the country, we do not have a sufficiently strong, independent body of advice coming from those statutory boards and councils that this Government has set up very much to work along with the government of the day. There is not enough independence in reporting to government about its conduct in higher education. In fact, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training is too close to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the councils. There are four of them, which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would know well. There is the Higher Education Council, the Schools Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council which, amongst other things, deals with TAFE and the Australian Research Council.

Those five bodies-the Board and the four councils-are all too close to the Department; they are dependent upon the Department's resources and they have become tame cats. It would appear that the Minister intended them to be tame cats. When have any of those bodies taken any public stand on any issue where they feel this Government is failing? We get a few suggestions at the margin. I am not saying something here which I have not said already to either the National Board or to the councils. I actually see enormous qualifications and experience being brought by individual members, in most cases to the Board and to the councils. That is not the quarrel.

The quarrel that the Opposition has is with the structure that makes them too easily the tame cats of the Government and, similarly, the failure to give them adequate resources to carry out the task of being advisory bodies. So they depend upon the Minister and the Department. They have to get resources and information as determined by the Department-and it is very convenient for this centralist Minister, Mr Dawkins, and his assistant Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin.

There needs to be a complete review of these matters. Independent advice on higher education and the other areas of education, employment and training is needed not only for its own sake but also so that the public sees it as such. The public, especially those involved in these education areas, should have full confidence that the advisory mechanisms are cognisant of the arguments that they would want to put, of the pleas that they would want to put. It should be ensured that the arguments are put as publicly as possible so that the public can trace what the Government does in response to them. At the moment all of that is too hidden.

In fact, the public is very likely to fall into the trap of feeling obliged to follow the agenda that the Government desires. We see the Dawkins approach in the way that institutions have been forced into all sorts of amalgamations, which have not been pursued by those involved for reasons of any education or merit. These institutions have been forced to respond to the financial imperatives of the Federal Government. `If you don't amalgamate, you won't get the same amount of money' is the sort of backroom pressure that this Government has made its distinguishing characteristic. I reject this kind of centralist approach.

Time and effort have been wasted even by those institutions not ultimately amalgamating. Institutions have had to spend a lot of time facing up to the shotgun at their head of this centralist Minister. They have to think it through, consult and explore whether the amalgamation is on. Even though many of the amalgamation proposals being forced by the Government have been eventually evaded, it has taken a lot of time and this country should have avoided this kind of distraction from education.

The Government's amalgamations agenda has been a disgrace. We just want to see the end of it, and we have been saying something like this for at least two years. Yet even when in this Senate chamber we saw an end to the legislation that was supposed to amalgamate the Australian National University (ANU) and the Canberra College of Advanced Education here in the national capital, we have found over recent months, particularly while the Senate was not sitting in the summer, another proposal being put by one of these tame cats, the Higher Education Council, to this Government to amalgamate the undergraduate part of the ANU with the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

We in the Opposition do not support that; the Australian Democrats do not support it. That was publicly known and yet the Government still persists. Professor Chubb, the particular appointee of Mr Dawkins to carry out an inquiry towards this end, came up with a report. It was as if he had not existed or had not known about the parliamentary debate for the past couple of years. He still proposed recommendations to amalgamate the two universities in this city despite all that had been said in the Parliament and despite all the expressed views of the ANU and even of the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

Many in those institutions in recent months have rightly said, `This Dawkins pressure that Chubb has given in to in recommending further amalgamation will destroy the ANU'. They say that it will-they use the word `destroy'-rip apart the school of general studies from the research institute at that university. The ANU is one of the most valuable higher education institutions that we have. Last Wednesday, in the `Higher Education' supplement published by the Australian, academics and students at the ANU-indeed, even the university council-were reported as totally opposing this agenda of destruction upon which the Labor Government still seems to be set. The headline is, `ANU scathing on Baldwin's latest proposal'. Professor Kurt Lambeck, who is the Rector of the university's Research School of Earth Scientists, said:
The past few years have been a time of turmoil and uncertainty. The university, or parts thereof, has been the subject of seemingly endless reviews.

The university has been requested to respond to government or government-initiated inquiries into all aspects of teaching and research. Initiated all too often by bureaucrats and politicians who appear to have little understanding of how a university functions, the reviews and reports are requested with great urgency and detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he complaining about accountability?

—He is not complaining about accountability. As a Minister of the Government, Senator Cook is only too aware that the number of reviews that have disturbed this university has been excessive. Even when this Senate, of which Senator Cook is a part, has ruled out the merger of the ANU with the Canberra University one sees his colleagues Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin persisting with yet another attempt to find some amalgamation. That has hit the dust and is history again-for the second, third or fourth time. Yet there does appear to be justice in these criticisms of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The criticisms are not being made of the Opposition; the criticisms are being made about the Government. That is what the article is referring to when it condemns bureaucrats and politicians. A change of government is way overdue. We need the Opposition's approach to higher education to dismiss this record of failure, this record of intrusion and this record of ignorant interference by politicians and bureaucrats-to quote what these academics have been saying, even as recently as a few days ago in the higher education supplement. Reference is made to this being an attempt by bureaucrats to be tidy; that is, to overcome some sort of innate call within a bureaucracy to get things ordered as they see fit for administrative reasons. I quote again from Professor Lambeck's remarks:
Better to stamp out this creativeness before it spreads to other areas. After all, if we're not careful, this approach could spread to the government departments themselves.

Also this past week at a graduation ceremony, the ANU's Professor of Economics, Professor Ross Garnaut, warned about `meagre and mediocre minds'. He is talking about those elements of Senator Cook's Government and his Government's bureaucracy that are interfering in the administration of the Australian National University. Professor Garnaut is a former adviser to the Prime Minister on economic matters and a person whom both Senator Cook and I respect. I am not quoting some isolated person we have just heard of; this is a person who carried out the Garnaut inquiry into Australia's economic relations with East Asia, our major trading centre. I endorse the Garnaut report. I value the insight, the experience and the views that are expressed by Professor Garnaut, and he is the one that is referring to meagre and mediocre minds. He wonders whether they are even capable of understanding a great university like the ANU. He is reported in the same supplement as saying:
A few days ago a Commonwealth minister said that `it is important that we develop a positive vision of the ANU'.
He goes on:
Meagre and mediocre minds are as incapable of seeing the reality of a great centre of scholarship, as of sharing the vision of whence it grew.

``The minister will come, I trust, to recognise the value in the established vision-lest his monument to Australian education and research be the destruction of a great institution, great and with capacity for further improvement yet, unique, and irreplaceable.
These are not light words. They are cries from the hearts and the minds of experienced people about what this Government is doing. I reject what this Government is doing.

The Opposition calls for a refreshing change completely away from the Dawkins agenda and completely away from the record of this Labor Government over recent years. I myself am convinced that this will come about only through a change of government. I remind the Senate of Mr Dawkins's words back on 15 June 1989 when he said:
. . . this Government has explicitly stated that it will support only mergers which have the support of the institutions concerned.

Can we still believe that that Minister has any credibility? What hollowness. It is a hollow claim that has turned out to ruin the credibility of the Minister now when we consider the financial pressure that is being placed on institutions to conform to this Government's centralist thinking.

Consider a current disgraceful example endangering the future of the Australian National University. I refer not only to the Chubb recommendations but also to the fact that there has not been sufficient consultation on a more respectable review, that which was carried out into the Research Institute at the ANU, in which a number of constructive findings were found. But let me put a very clear complaint, along with those I have put to the Senate in recent weeks, about this Government's conduct with regard to reports.

Today in the Senate there was only one paper tabled. It is entitled Response to the Review of the Institute of Advanced Studies: Report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. This report has been printed just recently but it is actually a letter of 14 January-three months ago. It is four pages of report from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training dated 14 January over the hand of the Chair, Dr Ramsey, to the Minister, Mr Peter Baldwin. We see it three months later, despite the fact that there is a conclusion at the end of Dr Ramsey's report, of which I remind the Minister, that this report needs:
. . . to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament as soon as practicable.

It is now three months later. I will not trespass upon a private conversation I had with the Minister, Mr Baldwin, just last Thursday night, but he said, `You are perhaps not aware, Baden, that the Government is not going to fully implement all that has been found in the Chubb report or in the Stephen report'-that the ANU in its Council's instructions and its appeal to stop the destruction is not aware that the Government is not going to go all the way down that agenda.

How do we know unless we are given reports? I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) very sincerely: why was this report not tabled at the beginning of February? It is only four pages long. What is the great problem in running that off on anyone's photocopying machine? It is symptomatic of the lack of information to this Parliament that when there is a hot debate running about what is to happen at the ANU, whether it is over the Chubb report or the Stephen report, we get such a piece of information from this tame cat, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, three months after it has been given to the Minister. This is why we had an amendment before this chamber, which was passed by the Senate, to reduce the reporting period of 15 days to five days. We did not persist with our amendment when the House of Representatives tossed it back to us because we knew that the Government was going to get around it administratively anyway.

This Government's record of informing the Parliament about higher education matters is deplorable. When I have a private conversation with the Minister, I welcome what he has to say to me in good faith, but I do not know the basis of his assumptions in that conversation because the Government, through its Ministers, has not brought information to the Parliament. This week we have these directly critical articles in the higher education supplement, in the publications of the Australian National University and so on. It is in the best interests of this Government to inform the Parliament what it is doing and what reports it has.

I was going to quote a very critical statement made by Professor McKinnon, the Vice-Chancellor of Wollongong, speaking as Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee (AVCC), when he decried the fact that the standards of and access that students have to higher education in Australia at the moment have gone down, have not improved and are worse under the Labor Government. It is right that he, as the Chairman of the AVCC, brings that clearly to people's attention. However, my time has gone so I cannot directly quote from the statements that he made, for instance, as reported in the Advertiser on 20 March, similarly in the Age and in various other newspapers in relation to the AVCC meeting in my city of Adelaide.

I will go quickly to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. As I said earlier, we are debating cognately two Bills. On behalf of the Opposition, with regard to the TAFE Bill, I move:
At the end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate deplores the Government's:
(a) failure to consider adequately the role of TAFE in its reform of the higher education sector;
(b) failure to take adequate steps to encourage the development of an open and flexible training market; and
(c) neglect of the warning of the Training Costs Review Committee that training must not become excessively burdened with the rigidities of the industrial relations system''.

In turning to the Opposition amendment and indeed to the inadequacies of this Government in the TAFE sector, we again find a situation where, under this Government, rigid and burdensome factors are being allowed to hinder the potential of this sector to contribute to the nation's economy.

I refer to the Deveson report which was published last October. The thrust of the report was to urge open and flexible training markets. I am sure that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, is very interested and wants to respond positively to the Deveson report because there is very much in it that is positive. In fact, it shows the inadequacies of the way in which TAFE has been administered from Canberra in recent years.

There do need to be changes and I want to urge them on the Government. It is in the direction of the Opposition amendment to make for more flexibility and for openness. I just have time to quote this sentence from the report:

Existing training arrangements comprise an unclear mixture of market and non-market driven activities. With market related activities growing rapidly and intruding into erstwhile non-market activities, the committee believes that clarification of the appropriate role of market processes in the overall training industry is urgently needed.

I conclude and cut short my speech by saying that the Government's record on TAFE and higher education is inadequate. It is a track record of failure. Whilst the only ultimate solution will be a change of government, I urge the Government to pay full attention to what the Parliament is saying and to bring about the changes that will improve both higher education and TAFE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sorts of concerns that have been expressed by Senator Teague during his speech are concerns which he is not alone in expressing. As he mentioned in his speech, recently there have been some quite public debates in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), especially with regard to higher education. Whilst on the surface these debates relate to the future of the Australian National University, the University of Canberra and the John Curtin School of Medical Research, they are providing a catalyst for many academics, institutional staff and tertiary students to question and publicly express their concerns about the direction of this Government's education policies.

SPEECH.PARA: It could be argued that some of the debate that has taken place so far in the ACT has been based, to some degree, on speculation. I agree with Senator Teague that some of that speculation may well have been reduced if the Government had presented its response to the document he referred to in his speech in a much more timely fashion. The Government's record in relation to information about higher education matters is deplorable. I suggest that could well be because it is embarrassed about the information which is now coming forth.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 and the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 that we are considering at the moment provide cost supplementation for the 1991 grants to the technical and further education (TAFE) and higher education sectors. In most respects these Bills concern fairly straightforward matters of financial administration. As well as allowing for inflation, they include the transfer of art and design courses in Queensland from the TAFE sector to higher education institutions. This apparently suits the trend in terms of course development and conformity; that is not to be debated by me here.

Within the Bills there are also provisions to spread out the payments over the years instead of providing a one-off amount under the special overseas postgraduate fund. This money that is the subject of this movement is a windfall from the equity and merit scholarship program due to chronic underexpenditure in that program. Perhaps it could at a later date be appropriate to ask questions about that underexpenditure. But, importantly, we should observe that, the essential factors in funding-the methods and levels of support for our tertiary institutions-are grossly inefficient, inadequate and inequitable.

The Auditor-General, in Audit Report No. 4 1990-91 on the Department of Employment, Education and Training, notes that cost supplementation indices have not been reviewed since 1984. That audit isolated a number of procedural and systems defects and abuses. It was noted that recurrent funding was neither in accordance with the established conditions nor in accordance with legislative requirements. Some payments were found to be not documented and not authorised. Other documents had been lost and prescribed actions had not been taken, especially, for instance, with regard to the acquittal of grants.

Turning in particular to higher education, those sorts of criticisms that I have just enumerated from the Auditor-General's report are not the only criticisms which should be directed to the system as it is now. The higher education sector is plagued by multiple crises in funding, overcrowding, shortages of academic staff and huge levels of unmet demand from qualified students. This phrase, `unmet demand', is one which has gained some currency in the media recently. It was suggested to me only at the weekend that the demand was caused by other factors. All sorts of suggestions were made about students not wanting to participate in the other sorts of activities that might be undertaken in the community. The fact is that these are qualified students who could and should be able to take advantage of the excellent schooling that they have had and the efforts that they have put in to reach the standard of being eligible for university entrance. But in demanding that entrance to higher education, their demand has been unable to be met because of the lack of foresight in this Government's education plans.

These and other major problems have been well documented, almost daily, in our national newspapers. We see evidence of over enrolment in higher education that has reached historically high records, with some institutions over enrolled of the order of 15 per cent. To be particular, the unmet demand was over 20,000 last year and, according to the early estimates that we have now, it could be as much as 30,000 for 1991.

An acute national shortage of academics of somewhere between 20,000, according to the report of Dr Blandy and the National institute for Labour Studies, and 25,000, according to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, will come to pass by the end of the decade. That can be measured at the moment, and we see no evidence that the Government's plans will bring about a change in that trend which has been identified by those two different sources.

Criticisms can be made, and we have examined the Opposition's plans to meet these criticisms. The Democrats cannot honestly support the Opposition's plans in their entirety either-which is not surprising, but is part of the way things are. The idea to charge fees for students after places have been filled, we think, is no solution to the many problems in this sector-the problems that have been caused by government policy.

I will move on to TAFE funding and what the Government has in mind there. I suggest that it is not a strong cooperative network of various educational and training opportunities, but an extension of compulsory tertiary fees to ensure that TAFE courses are no longer affordable as the only post-secondary education available to generations of bright, interested Australian students. We have seen what happened with the introduction of TAFE fees in New South Wales in 1988 which, it has now been estimated, has been responsible for a decline of 100,000 students over two years. Instead of creating a climate of cooperation where we can build a more intelligent and equitable Australia, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who oversees this master plan, wants to see a situation where TAFE is competing with private companies for funding. What we really see is that this Minister's topsy-turvy education policies are, in fact, mean, discriminatory and illogical.

The record in this whole area of education is smeared with disgrace. We have the Dawkins rhetoric about institutional autonomy under a uniform national system, and we know that that is a fraud. It is now broadly realised that Mr Dawkins has increasingly interfered with institutions and extended the scope for much greater government control. Institutional autonomy may be the rhetoric, but what is delivered is, as Senator Teague described, a centralist approach which is called one thing and, in fact, turns out to be something else.

One of the many severe critics of the Minister's plans comes from a growing lobby of educators, community groups and citizens who have been cast by the Minister's Green Paper as the guardian angels of national policy on languages. I think the Minister should be advised that more than one of these people find it hard to endorse the policies that are described in the Green Paper. One senior lecturer at La Trobe University, Helen Moore, in a paper which was issued in January 1991 entitled, `Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages: An Australian Perspective', considers policy changes in relevant sectors. In paragraph 2.4 on page 30 Ms Moore describes policy developments in higher education and states:
In many of the Minister's policy documents and pronouncements, not just the Green Paper, he has shown himself to be a master of malign displacements.
In regard to higher education, he has claimed that current reforms are motivated by a belief in institutional autonomy.
In fact, this rhetoric is being used to establish closer control of both intellectual and organisational life in higher education.
With regard to the development of education under the overseas student policy as an export industry, Ms Moore is even more scathing. She states:
If for nothing else, he-
Mr Dawkins-

should be sacked as the Minister responsible for this wicked fiasco, marked by the inefficiency and stupidity of his own Department, scandalous fraud within the private sector which his Department supposedly monitors, the coercion and debasement of teachers . . .
She continues:
. . . and young people forced to maintain themselves at best by working for wages that bear no relation to award standards and at worst involved in prostitution and presumably drugs.

Of particular relevance to the Dawkins approach to education as an economic resource, is this paper's review of the argument that our understanding of the university is changing. On page 44 Ms Moore summarises as follows:

The essence of postmodernist thought is a critique of the notions of truth, moral values and the unity of knowledge. We are now more comfortable with the assumption of multiple truths, each as good as the other.
She continues on page 45 as follows:
The reality now is that, with the loss of acceptance of knowledge and truth as uncontested meanings, the basis for the state's toleration of the university's autonomy has also disappeared.
It appears that the consequence of this loss of autonomy is that university programs and research are competing against other claims for resources, and even competing for their very existence.

The pursuit of truth is no longer the privilege of universities. Helen Moore concludes that under the Dawkins model, `in fact, purse strings and power are the only truth'. That is evident in the sorts of plans that Senator Teague referred to with regard to the Australian National University. That is the very reason why we should question those plans. There has been little evidence given to us by people who have participated in the debate that the guiding factor in making those plans has been the desire to see academic improvement. In fact, we would be forgiven for thinking that the only factor has been something to do with the rationalisation of expenditure. As such, we would find it very hard to endorse those plans.

The Australian Democrats believe that education should be supported as a lifelong opportunity for all, and that further education should benefit not only the individual but also our society as a whole. The danger of accepting the Government's view and, indeed, the Opposition's view, that education is a cost is one of which we should be very wary. We see evidence that on the scale of priorities education, health and welfare do not fare well under the policies of the major parties.

This patch-up Bill may provide a short term answer to some of the problems in education, and for that reason we will not be opposing it, but, in the long term, the malaise in education will not be ameliorated in any way by this Bill. So although we will allow the passage of the Bill, we take the opportunity to be most critical of the policies of which it is a part.

In the short time that we have had to consider the several amendments that will be moved by the Opposition, we have been tempted to support them. We would be particularly tempted if the amendment to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 had included a certain word. For Senator Teague's benefit, we would have appreciated it if the amendment had read, `deplores the Government's failure to provide the sector with the finances, the flexibility and the incentives it needs to address the academic staff shortage.' If the amendment had included the words, `the finances', we would have been even more tempted to support it. Rather than guarantee support of that amendment and the other amendments at this moment, we will listen to the debate with interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 and the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 cognately. Those Bills will provide increased funding for higher education institutions totalling $171m over the period 1991-1993. These supplementation costs will amount to an additional $54m in 1991, $58m in 1992 and $59m in 1993. The Opposition will not be opposing either of these amendment Bills, but we do oppose very strenuously the efforts of the Hawke Government to destroy what was once considered a very fine higher education system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Government interference with and intervention into higher education has had catastrophic results. We now have a bureaucratically administered system dominated by ministerial discretion. We have lost essential flexibility and incentives to maintain our internationally competitive higher education system with world-class standards. Competition in the education marketplace has given way to competition for bureaucratic favours. Our institutions have been bullied, bludgeoned and blackmailed into forced amalgamations or new institutional arrangements by the threat of withholding capital grants.

I have come to this place from the higher education sector and I have observed from the inside the chaos that is created by the heavy-handed interference of this Hawke Labor Government. Students who enrolled at the Newcastle College of Advanced Education in 1987 went on to spend the second and third years of study at the Hunter Institute of Higher Education in 1988 and 1989 and then finally graduated from the University of Newcastle after 1990. In other words, students had to pass through three major organisational changes during one course of study. I leave to the imagination of honourable senators the disruption and chaos that this caused as staff were constantly distracted from their proper work of teaching and research to cope with the massive problems created by administrative change.

When I was on sabbatical leave in the United States (US) four years ago, a professor told me that the changes in higher education that Australia had been subject to over a period of 20 years had occurred in the US over 90 years. He said this before the so-called Dawkins revolution. We have had extraordinary change on top of rapid change and the staff in the universities have been brought almost to breaking point.

As part of the most recent change, we have another bureaucratic impost-the education profile. I will remind honourable senators what education profiles are. These are mechanisms which are designed to balance the freedom of institutions to manage their own affairs with the need of public accountability. They represent agreements which are negotiated annually between the Commonwealth and higher education institutions. They define the institution's broad mission together with its teaching and research responsibilities. They also establish the institution's particular area of activity and specific goals as the basis on which to receive Commonwealth funding.

The results of the education profile process have been deplorable. The Government now has considerable scope for telling institutions what they can teach, what research they can undertake and how they should manage their affairs. The education profile process opens the way for extensive government intrusion into matters where governments should keep out. There are already complaints from institutions that the Commonwealth Government imposes excessive and unnecessary demands on institutions for information and that the Government is unnecessarily intrusive in their affairs.

Last week Professor Lambeck told graduands at the Australian National University (ANU) that the University had been requested to respond to government inquiries into all aspects of teaching and research. The Government appears to have little understanding of how a university functions when these reviews and reports are requested with great urgency and detail.

The approach of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) reflects his socialist passion for control. The name `unified national system' says it all. It sounds like a program out of the old eastern Europe with its command economy. While eastern Europe was moving towards greater deregulation and freedom, flexibility and competition, Minister Dawkins was forcing Australia in higher education into the Dark Ages of regulation and inflexibility, a command system for our universities.

The former president of Romania would have been very proud of our Mr Dawkins's command system. The results of this national unified system are only too apparent in the universities of the nation. Five years ago, we had the so-called Dawkins revolution. Let us have a look at the effects it has had over the last five years. It has affected student numbers. This year about 20,000 qualified students were turned away from higher education institutions, thus blocking their opportunity to achieve their potential and stunting our growth as a nation.

Staff morale is at an all time low and workloads continue to rise. I should know because I have been subject to them over the last 10 years. We have been told of one staff member conducting a tutorial designed for 20 students but having more than double that number packed into a room to hold a maximum of 15 people. In the humanities and social science departments, the real crunch will come when reports and essays flood in for marking and staff attempt to cope with additional assignment work. I know what that involves. In one course I was conducting four years ago, I had about 30 assignments to mark; that went up to 45 and last year I had 70 assignments to mark on a regular basis, coming in about once a month. Those assignments were in only one of the courses that I was teaching.

On top of this, we have staff shortages in universities and these are approaching crisis proportions. By the year 2000, it is projected that there will be an academic staff shortage of 25,000. Stories of student overcrowding in lecture halls appear in the newspapers almost every day. In last Tuesday's Sydney Morning Herald, Professor Richard Blandy of Flinders University stated:

You've got 300 in the class in front of you, you lose eye contact at row six, there's a video camera pointing at you, there are . . . students in the first three of four rows with recorders . . . Here you are, having to meet their needs in economics one. You're wired for sound, there are 150 out in the overflow room watching on the big screen.
I know I'm a terrific teacher and I just bleed inside. I look in the eyes of those bright-eyed bushy-tailed kids and I know I'm trying, they're trying and together we'll fail . . .

Yet there is little chance of attracting academic staff from overseas, given the low level of salary inducement. The centralised wages system is a major impediment to alleviating the situation. The system currently involves long and tortuous negotiations. Academics have become so frustrated that last year they took the unprecedented step of refusing to process examination results. This created, at the end of last year, administrative chaos but it was an act of desperation which arose out of a slip in their standard of living. Since 1974, the standard of living and the value of salaries of academics has dropped 30 per cent.

The latest wage offer which is supposed to help redress this is little more than a joke. A professor telephoned me last week to tell me that under the latest offer his new take-home pay will be $5 more a week; for tutors it will be even less. We desperately need the kind of deregulation in the academic staff market that will permit flexibility and competition in order to attract and retain outstanding staff in Australia. If market forces are not allowed to have any influence on setting the salaries of academics, people in high demand by industry-for example, people in computing and accountancy-will leave the universities and this will further reduce the standard of teaching and research.

The Blandy report has indicated that there will be substantial requirements for additional staff over the next decade. But how does the Government plan to attract high-quality staff when salaries are so low and working conditions are deteriorating so rapidly? Our staff shortages will have the long term effect of reducing recruitment standards, together with declining teaching and research standards as staff-student ratios are allowed to increase beyond their already unsatisfactory levels.

It has been my experience in higher education that these levels have been rising for 10 years. This is not surprising when Ministers display their complete lack of understanding of the nature of university work. Recently, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, claimed that academics need not hold a higher degree. What a peculiar claim. If all academics are expected to carry out research and to teach others to take part in this process they need to have a higher degree; this is their professional qualification. It is the only means by which they acquire competence in their subject which, in turn, gives them the authority and the knowledge to teach others in a university.

Perhaps the worst aspect of this Government's heavy-handed interventionist command approach to higher education is in the area of forced amalgamations. I remind the Senate that only two years ago the Minister said:
The Government has explicitly stated that it will support only mergers which have the support of the institutions concerned.

But what has actually happened? There have been continued threats to the Australian National University, to take one example of a proposed forced merger. The Chubb report recommended that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the faculties of the ANU and that the faculties, in turn, be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. The ANU, its staff and its councils have totally rejected these recommendations. They claim that it would not be in the interests of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), nor would it be in the interests of Australia. They further claim that the ACT would lose a major educational asset if the ANU were split, and it would be a long time, if ever, before university education in the ACT again achieved the status that it has currently through the ANU.

However, for these recommendations to be put in place appropriate legislation will have to be put before the Federal Parliament. If such legislation were to be introduced while the ANU and the ACT opposed the split, the amalgamation would be a clear and unambiguous violation of the commitment of the Minister to support only those mergers which had the support of the institutions concerned.

In the case of my own institution, the University of Newcastle was forced to amalgamate with the Hunter Institute of Higher Education. Both institutions resisted this merger for eight years. Neither side wanted it, but in the end they were forced into it by a relentless government-the same government that claimed to support only those mergers which had the support of the institutions. The obstacles to the amalgamation were gargantuan. The institutions had different administrative systems; everything had to be redesigned. This is an example of economic efficiency: a totally new telephone system had to be installed because the two telephone systems were different and totally incompatible.

The missions of the university and the institute were quite different. The institute was originally vocationally oriented and the university focused not only on some vocation but also on liberal education. Following on from the differences in mission, the institute staff were paid to be involved in lecturing only whereas the university staff were expected to be lecturers and researchers. As a result, the staffing of the two institutions was quite different. In order to fit into the university mission, staff of the institute had to change dramatically: from being employed only as lecturers they had to change their work functions and many had to upgrade their qualifications in order to perform essential research functions in a university. They also had to undertake a different style of lecturing. We are now moving to a system which involves larger lecture groups and less individual guidance for students who are trying to learn complex subject matter. This is hardly the way to create the clever country-particularly if students have difficulty understanding the subject matter.

The problem with higher education is that much of the effort which has gone into the amalgamation of institutions has to do with administrative, not educational, objectives. But even there the Government's policy has failed. Higher education institutions have lost the capacity to respond flexibly because of new inappropriate internal structures and excessive government regulation. Only two weeks ago Leonie Kramer said that we cannot produce a flexible work force in this country by creating a higher education system where the Federal Government is dominant. She said:
If you want flexibility, you have to encourage diversity and independence.
The Hawke Government's national unified system is not the answer. Therefore, it will be up to us, the Opposition, to maintain a vigorous debate on higher education.

I will indicate, very briefly, to the Senate that the Opposition policy on higher education is quite different from the direction in which we have been travelling for the last five years. Our approach is to move towards a more competitive system with less government regulation, better access to private funding and a more open system of public accountability. Earlier, the Minister said that all of these heavy-handed controls were for the purpose of accountability. There are other ways to achieve this without totally stultifying the institution.

We will restore autonomy to higher education institutions. We will allow them greater freedom to chart their own futures without the conformist constraints that are presently upon them. We will provide incentives for institutions to improve their performance without government intervention. We will stimulate healthy competition amongst institutions which will promote excellence of achievement among students and staff.

There can be no doubt that higher education is of utmost importance in this country. Australia is a modern industrial nation with the potential of developing into a leading technologically-advanced society. Our future prosperity will depend upon our willingness to push back the frontiers of knowledge and to exploit new alternatives. Our prosperity and the quality of our lives will depend greatly on our capacity to provide our youth with an excellent education which is not just training in specific skills. Higher education in Australia is at the crossroads. It should contribute to our economic development, but it should also contribute to our cultural enrichment. Each institution must have sufficient freedom to determine its own directions and goals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 and the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. The first Bill will provide a cost supplementation for funding for States, Territories and higher education institutions, and the second Bill will change some existing grants to the States for technical and further education as a result of the transfer of certain courses from the TAFE sector to other parts of the higher education sector in Queensland. Neither of the Bills, as is indicated by what I have said, is very contentious. They provide for an additional $171m to be allocated to the tertiary sector to be spread over three years which, given the total amount needed in the area, is not particularly large at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose these Bills but, regrettably, it is necessary to speak on the Bills-even at some length-lest it be thought that in not doing so we were in fact supporting the Government's policy in the area of higher education. I think this is the time for us to review it.

The failures of this Government are: increasing interference and interventionist policies; the policy of forced amalgamations; to make inroads into the level of unmet demand; reduced funding per student; staff salaries declining by up to one-third, relative to weekly earnings, since 1974; to provide tertiary institutions with freedom and flexibility to address this impending shortage of academic staff; neglect of the fundamental issue of equality in education; and disruption and continuing insecurity in these institutions.

All of this has an impact on the students who are attempting to benefit from tertiary education in this country. I wish to go through this in a little more detail. First, I refer to the increasing interference and interventionist policies of the Government in higher education. The whole higher education system is being brought under increasing and direct political control by the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), and this has led inevitably to an undermining of institutional autonomy. This is illustrated by the whole concept of a unified system and the intrusive educational profiles process which continues to be an administrative nightmare and is totally related to undue central control. Mr Frank Hambly, the Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, said on 28 September 1990:

. . . the reality is that there is scope for much more government control over higher education than there was in the past.
