For example, through the educational profile process the Government has considerable scope for telling institutions what they can teach, what research they can undertake and how they should manage their affairs.

There is little doubt that the Federal Minister is attempting to achieve a uniform system of tertiary education and not just a unified system. The whole policy is more about central control of education than national standards, more about bureaucratic control under the Minister's direction than the benefit to students who are studying in our institutions. In August 1989 Professor Peter Karmel argued that the Dawkins reforms meant that the Federal Government was intervening more in tertiary institutions and warned that the bureaucratic tendency to coordinate, which is a euphemism for control, must be watched closely.

The second point I mention is the policy of the forced amalgamations since 1988. Amalgamations have produced some sort of cult that big is better. Some of the amalgamations made sense; others did not. Senator Tierney has just referred to the one that he was involved in with the University of Newcastle. Regardless of whether the proposed amalgamations were appropriate or wanted, higher education institutions have been bullied by the threat of withholding capital grants into forced amalgamations and new institutional arrangements, in spite of the Minister's comment that no institution would be forced to amalgamate if it did not wish to do so. At no time during the debate on amalgamations in 1988 or since have I heard the Australian Labor Party express amalgamations in terms of benefits to students. How often have we in this place asked the Government to explain the benefits to students? All of us might have taken a quite different approach to amalgamation had it been expressed in terms of benefits to students. They seem to be the least of the Minister's concerns.

This industry restructuring under increasing central control has failed to introduce flexibility and incentives to allow higher education in Australia to maintain and extend an internationally competitive higher education system. Failure to make inroads into the level of unmet demand is perhaps one of the most significant points. The Government has demonstrated a total inability to provide tertiary places for those Australians who desperately want to further their studies. There have been quite dramatic increases in the retention rates of students continuing to year 12 in our secondary schools, and that is particularly the case in the Australian Capital Territory. This Government is very inclined to boast about the increasing numbers completing year 12. It is frequently heard that the Government is very proud of the fact; but what is the point in this if it then cannot offer students the opportunity to pursue their education to university or into the technical and further education area? The TAFE populations are expanding and there is an unprecedented demand for university places. However, having been encouraged to go that far, having been encouraged to recognise that education beyond secondary level is of benefit, many students are now disillusioned at finding that they are unable not just to get into the courses they wanted but to get into a university or a TAFE college. This, of course, causes real problems. I believe that it causes social problems as well in that those who have been built up to believe that they would be able to achieve something, to pursue a course, suddenly find that, having gone to year 12, they are virtually thrown onto the scrap heap and invited to take up unemployment benefits. It is a failure adequately to fund opportunities for an increasing number of people who want to take them.

We hear about the clever country. It is clear that the numbers able to obtain employment in manufacturing are dropping. It is only in this area that this country has a future. At the same time that the Government has reduced the opportunity for those who are qualified to take up places in tertiary institutions, we find that there is reduced funding per student. In 1990, 75,000 more students than in 1983 passed through the system-a positive achievement. However, they received 12 per cent less funding per full time student. This fact was dramatically illustrated by Jon Coroneos, the President of the Australian National University (ANU) Students Association, when on 22 March 1990 he stated:

The federal Government has in many ways been the principal cause of the malaise currently sweeping through universities. The education policy of the Government is to increase tertiary student numbers without any increase in funding.

The funding levels are worth noting. In 1985 funding per student was $11,500, in 1990 funding per student was $8,700, and in 1992 funding per student is planned to be $8,200. I do not need to point out that the value of money has not been going in the same direction. In fact, the amount per student being lost is quite considerable.

The impact of that brings me to my fifth point-staff salaries. While available funds are being cut back, it is inevitable that the value of salaries of staff will decline. It is a fact that in many of the institutions we still have very dedicated members of staff who, notwithstanding the loss of earnings as a result of the Government's policies, have stayed in the institutions and are very committed to education. But that will not be the case for ever. If this continues, the time will come when it is impossible to attract into our tertiary institutions people with the necessary qualifications to be good teachers. They just will not want to be there; they will want to go where they can earn a reasonable living.

Staff salaries have declined by up to one-third relative to the average weekly earnings since 1974. At the same time, staff workloads have increased, promotional opportunities have been reduced and research funding is more difficult to obtain. Unless there are significant and positive changes in staff conditions, it is estimated, reliably and reasonably, that there will be massive staff shortages.

In my opinion, staff morale remains at an all-time low: salaries falling relative to average weekly earnings, staff shortages increasing, more and more students wanting to get into institutions, and little likelihood that academic staff will be attracted to this country from overseas. Where will the tertiary institutions get their staff from in five or 10 years time? I hope that when it happens the Senate will remember that we have pointed it out now. The present Commonwealth-controlled rationing system does not allow the flexibility to attract and retain outstanding staff.

To use one example, I refer to the salaries in the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University. In 1974 a professor of law received a salary which was the same as that for a district court judge. Currently, a professor at the ANU in the Faculty of Law receives a salary which is one-half of the value of a district court judge. That is how far the salary levels have gotten out of kilter since 1974, and that is what we are doing to our students: failing to pay lecturers and professors at a rate which will attract good people into the institutions. As I said, luckily we still have many good staff members who are prepared to stay in the institutions because they are committed to what they are doing.

A legal secretary these days with no tertiary qualifications will be paid as much as a lecturer in law at a university. The Government might think it is saving money by doing that, but it is certainly destroying the education system.

The next point I wish to raise is the failure to provide institutions with the freedom and flexibility that they need to address the impending shortage of academic staff to which I have referred. It has been suggested that there will be a shortage of up to 25,000 staff by the year 2000. Higher education in Australia under this Government is financially bound to the Commonwealth Government. It operates within a rigid framework of regulation-the profile funding mechanism with threats of withdrawal of funds if people do not do what the Minister wants-which has restricted and frustrated the capacity of tertiary institutions to compete for staff, students and resources. The Government has failed to give institutions the flexibility to offer Australian students additional places on terms acceptable to both.

What about the quality of education? Senator Aulich, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, has acknowledged that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, is so absorbed in financial and structural change that he has neglected the really fundamental issue of quality in tertiary education. What a condemnation of any education Minister.

Uniformity does not automatically produce quality in tertiary education; in fact, without competition between institutions for top staff, students, courses, et cetera, there is a risk of complacency and mediocrity rather than a striving for excellence. The Blandy report from the National Institute of Labour Studies argues:

. . . the inevitable long-term effects (of current staff shortages) include reduction in recruitment standards together with declining teaching and research standards as staff-student ratios are allowed to increase beyond optimal levels.
Again, in the report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training entitled Higher Education: The Challenges Ahead, it is stated:

. . . there is relationship between the level of funding of higher education and its quality. The closer the funding base is to the margin, the more difficult it is for the system to be able to deliver the quality.

The Government may well boast a 50 per cent increase in tertiary enrolments since Labor came into government, but funding has not kept pace with this. Funding has declined by 11 per cent, and that means that students are not getting the same education. As a proportion of our gross domestic product, Commonwealth expenditure on higher education was 1.05 per cent in 1980-81 and by 1989-90 it was 0.85 per cent.

All of this leads to disruption and continuing insecurity in institutions. The Government's policies have caused a chronic and crippling uncertainty. As the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), said in the other place on 13 March 1991, an enormous disaffection exists within the higher education sector towards the Government and its disruptive and damaging policies. That of course affects teaching in institutions.

All of these factors can be illustrated by what has happened to the Australian National University. I go back over the story. In July 1988 the proposal was to amalgamate the Australian National University with the then Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). It was put forward as part of the Dawkins's plan for higher education. It was evident that the Minister was more concerned with administrative neatness and control than with increasing educational standards. On 12 August 1989, Mr Dawkins said:
There is no question in my mind that the amalgamation would result in a university more appropriate to the emerging shape of the unified national system of higher education in Australia.

But what about the educational advantages? There was not a word of that. It was all to do with being more appropriate to the emerging shape of the unified national system of higher education in Australia, no matter what happened to the ANU and the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

TALK.START.PARA: —No matter what happened to the students.

—And no matter what happened to the students, as Senator Teague just said. Even in August 1989, at that relatively early stage in this ongoing and disruptive saga, the Minister is quoted in a press article as being sympathetic to the concerns raised by the university and the CCAE about the damage that would be done to its academic programs if there were to be continuing, drawn out uncertainty about their future status and mission. It is now April 1991 and the uncertainty continues to this time, even though the Minister said that no institutions would be forced to amalgamate if they did not wish to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1989 the proposed amalgamation of the ANU, CCAE and the Canberra Institute of the Arts was called off after the ANU Council voted against the merger. The following was reported in the Canberra Times on 13 September 1989:
There will definitely be no amalgamation between the ANU and the CCAE, according to the Minister for Education, John Dawkins.

No sooner did CCAE change its name to the University of Canberra than the proposed amalgamation was back on again. I believe-and Senator McMullan can correct me if I am wrong-that at that time he too called for an end to the speculation on the future of Canberra's tertiary institutions, recognising that it was time that they be allowed to get on with the jobs they were supposed to be doing. That was in September 1989.

Regrettably, that was not to be the end of the saga. On 3 January 1990, the Minister announced the appointment and terms of reference of a committee which was to review the Institute of Advanced Studies of the ANU. Its report is known as the Stephen report. Page 1 of that report says:

The Committee believes that the Institute continues to have an important role to play as a major Australian centre of research and of research training at the highest level and that it can best perform these roles as a constituent part of the ANU.

What happened after that, one can only speculate about, but the next thing we knew Professor Ian Chubb, Chairman of the Higher Education Council, was asked to prepare a report on the implementation of the Stephen report. I really cannot explain what happened, but there is no relationship whatsoever between the recommendations of the Chubb report and what was recommended in the Stephen report. It seems to me to be much more likely that what is recorded in the Chubb report is what the Minister was aiming to do in the first place-that is, amalgamate the institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Dawkins pushed it.

—I have not talked to Mr Dawkins or Professor Chubb, though the outcomes seem to be putting into effect precisely what Minister Dawkins had in mind in 1988. The implementation of the recommendations of the Chubb report would have meant the disintegration of the Australian National University and the loss to Australia of its international and national reputation. That would be a tragedy for education in this country. It certainly would be a tragedy for Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that this community has to offer is that it is a place of excellence in education. There is a whole range of institutions and courses in Canberra, such as the national baccalaureate course at Narrabundah College. A number of places offer courses that people come to Canberra to undertake. At the top of the tree is the Australian National University. To destroy that would undermine the total benefits for this Territory of the educational institutions that have been built up over a period.

With the Chubb report, the debates about amalgamation, merger, takeover or whatever one might see it as, started all over again, continuing the uncertainty that exists in both institutions as to what their future really holds and where they are going.

In March 1991, following an overwhelming rejection of the split of the institutions and the proposals of the Chubb report, the Minister announced that the recommendations would not be implemented. However, that was not the end of it. The Minister stated his intention to continue to push for a merger between the ANU and the University of Canberra and decided to separate the John Curtin School of Medical Research from the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU. There just seems to be no end to the Minister's desire to destroy that institution.

Nobody is suggesting that there is not room for change, that there is not room for working more closely together. I believe that that is happening. But the Minister seems to have at heart this hell-bent desire to destroy what has been achieved. It is interesting that on 15 June 1989 the Minister stated that only mergers would go ahead that were supported by the institutions. But in Canberra we have suffered for three years from this instability.
Dr Des Nicholls, Dean of the Faculty of Economics and Commerce at the ANU, summed up what has happened to the ANU. In an article reported in the Canberra Times on 13 March 1991, he said:

. . . the instability into which Australian tertiary education has been cast; the continued threats to the ANU as an institution; a real reduction in academic salaries and the lack of flexibility of appointments and salaries within the ANU itself.
This illustrates the insensitivity and the destructive power of the Dawkins's approach and, ultimately, the irresponsibility of the Government's handling of higher education in this country.

As I said at the beginning, we are discussing two Bills which relate to funding and administration of higher education and institutes of technical and further education. But I could not let the opportunity pass without referring to these important matters which have arisen from Government policy over recent years. I could also mention the attack of the Minister on the Bond University, which he described as an abject failure. He seems to be totally negative about anything. I also refer to the uncertainty which exists, particularly in the Australian National University.

Until the Government adopts different policies, until it adopts the policies which we have espoused, there will be no opportunity for more places and better quality education in our tertiary institutions. As Professor McNicol, the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University, said in the University of Sydney News:
. . . the present system is so manifestly unable to provide the funds needed to satisfy people's expectations of higher education that other alternatives must be urgently canvassed . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make some brief general remarks to bring us back to the purposes of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 and the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. As is appropriate on a very important issue such as tertiary education, this has been a somewhat wide-ranging debate. The Bills before us deal with increased funding and supplementation-increased funding for tertiary education under the Higher Education Funding Act and supplementation under the TAFE funding Act.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills, while not controversial-and this is what speakers have been saying-do give honourable senators the opportunity to range widely over the important issue of the nature of the future funding and size of our tertiary education institutions and the importance that that has for a country that must increasingly give attention to the education and training of its work force. In this instance, I am talking not just of conventional education and training to do with higher education but on-the-job training, important issues to do with TAFE and so on.

If this is to be the clever country, if we are to maximise the economic return from the human resources available to Australia, we have to continue to maximise the attention and the consideration given to education issues broadly and, for the purposes of this debate, higher education issues. I welcome the fact that there has been such an interested and wide-ranging debate.

I want to give a specific response to matters that were mentioned by Senator Reid, given their domestic concern to me. I also want to give a more detailed response to some questions which I understand Senator Teague raised. I am sorry that I was not in the chamber to hear his speech but I have a detailed response which I will read into the record. I hope that that will be of assistance to him. I will make only a brief response to the amendment which is, in fact, just a continuation of the ongoing debate about tertiary education. Although the points raised are not new, I want to refer to them.

Senator Reid raised questions about the Australian National University (ANU), the University of Canberra and higher education in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). She and I have publicly and in this place talked about this for several years. I do not want to go over much of the well-known ground. I do not think the debate is enhanced by talking about-

TALK.START.PARA: —You are too embarrassed.

—I am happy to talk about it. I was about to say that I was quite happy to say publicly that I did not agree with the Chubb report. I do not think we ought to reflect-and Senator Reid did not-on the integrity of Professor Chubb. I think he went about his work responsibly. But he came to a conclusion with which I disagreed. I am pleased that his recommendation has not been adopted and I expressed that view publicly. This is very unusual. I do not usually make public comments on matters that are under consideration within the Government. I think the most appropriate thing for someone in a position like me to do is to make comments inside the Government. But I thought this matter was of such local significance and my views were sufficiently strong that I should make that comment publicly. I had previously made it to Professor Chubb, so he would not have been surprised in the slightest. I am disappointed that he came to that conclusion. I think his views about the Institute of Advanced Studies were wrong and I am pleased that the Minister did not proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the release of the Chubb report I have had the opportunity to have discussions with the Minister, with representatives of the ANU and particularly with people from the Institute of Advanced Studies. I hope that the discussions which took place before the ANU Council-and those which will be precipitated by the decisions of the ANU Council-will lead to a more efficient and a more effective higher education sector in the ACT.

While I think it is important that the Institute of Advanced Studies continues as a separate research institution within and attached to the ANU, it is also important that we get the coordination of higher education here, particularly between the ANU and the University of Canberra and, to the extent that it is possible, the Australian Defence Force Academy. I think that is a desirable reform and we ought to continue to press for that enhanced coordination.

I think the higher education institutions in the ACT need the opportunity to get on with educating students. They should not have to spend so much time talking about how we are going to organise the institutions to do that. I have said that publicly; I have said it to Minister Dawkins; I have said it to Minister Baldwin; and I look forward to that happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do they still keep doing it?

—I think the Institute of Advanced Studies needed review. I do not think anyone has actually argued that. I thought the Stephen report was very worthwhile. The initial proposal with regard to Professor Chubb was to try and look at the integration of the Stephen report with other matters. I do not want to speak too much about the Chubb report and other matters because we do not have the time to do so. But if the institutions would stop coming to the Government complaining about each other, the administration of higher education in this Territory would be much better done. I have told the parties concerned. Any Minister for education would say that he spends more of his time than objectively can be justified having to deal with squabbles between the ANU and the University of Canberra, given their place in the overall scheme of higher education. Both of those institutions and their administrations are subject to some criticism in that regard. I would not normally say that, but I have said it to them privately and I do not need to be embarrassed about saying it publicly. Let us get on with the education function.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to respond to Senator Teague's request for more information on the amendments regarding the special overseas postgraduate fund. In 1989, the Government determined new arrangements for the funding of overseas students. Under these arrangements, the subsidised overseas students program is phased out. Newly commencing overseas students are required to pay full tuition fees from 1990.

The Government allocated additional funding to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to fund scholarships to assist overseas students to study in Australia. This additional funding was designed to maintain the Commonwealth financial commitment through the aid budget for overseas students to study in Australia. I think that has led to a more accurate definition of the nature of the assistance that is being provided. It is being more appropriately recorded. This is a reform that is generally supported.

In the 1990-91 Budget, the Government reviewed the implementation of the new arrangements and took a decision to establish a special overseas postgraduate fund to finance scholarships to assist overseas students to undertake postgraduate study in Australia. The amount was legislated in the 1990 Budget session as a total amount for expenditure in 1991 pending detailed discussions on the establishment of the program. The Department has now had an opportunity to undertake discussions with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee to develop a detailed program which will be spread over a number of years for the management of the fund. The proposed amendment gives effect to the cash flow required for the program. I hope that information assists Senator Teague. If there is anything I can get subsequently, if he will let me know I will try to arrange it for him.

I do not want to take up a great deal of the time of the Senate with amendments. Second reading amendments-I do not intend to minimise them-tend to be re-statements of public positions. Senator Teague and I have been debating higher education in previous motions in this place, and more particularly and importantly Ministers representing the Minister for Education over the years have debated this issue with Opposition representatives, including Senator Teague and the front bench people responsible. It is important that we do not ignore the fact that some of the problems in higher education at the moment are problems of growth. We might wish that they were being dealt with differently or whatever, but many are problems emerging from a significant increase in the number of tertiary education places-if my memory serves me correctly, a program for some 70,000 extra places over the period to 1993. That is a very important increase. If people then want to say that we should have handled the increase differently or that we should have managed such and such in a different way, those questions are worthy of debate and have been debated here on many occasions in the past. We get all sorts of arguments about the way in which these things are handled.

I want to respond to only one of them, that to which Senator Bell referred, not particularly in relation to the amendment but in the second reading debate as a whole. He referred to perceived shortcomings in the financial administration of the higher education program on which the Auditor-General reported to Parliament. It is important not to minimise that criticism, but to point out that they were based on the 1988 program year. Those criticisms have been addressed by the Department, and my advice is that the more recent audits of the program undertaken by the Audit Office have established that there are no longer those serious problems relating to the financial administration of the program. I think I can say that the Auditor-General was right to raise the matter, and probably has done his duty in enhancing financial administration in the public sector, but it is not a reflection on the existing situation. For those reasons I indicate that the Government will be opposing the second reading amendments. I commend the Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last day of sitting I mentioned that 23 March 1991 was an important day for democracy in Queensland. It was also a very important day for democracy throughout Australia in that it could well be the last major election where citizens have the right of free speech in this country; that is, the right to lobby and the right to put their point of view in the media in the way they believe most effective-not just effective in getting their message across but cost-effective. That could well have been the last time that form of election at the local government level will take place in Queensland, because if the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has its way it will ban free speech in this country and prevent the people of this nation from being able to advertise and to get their message across in the most effective way that they know.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should not be allowed to tell people how and how not they can get their message across. The Government should not be able to tell people that they can exercise their right of free speech only in certain ways. The banning of political advertising, even if it is only a minor infringement on a person's free speech, is a terrible shame, a terrible step for this nation to take with regard to democracy. Senator Bolkus would have us understand-so he says in support of his proposals to ban free speech, to ban political advertising-that television advertising is only for the rich, that it is very costly and that people cannot exercise their free speech now because the costs simply prohibit all but the very wealthy from doing that.

Senator Bolkus uses misleading figures-as does the ALP generally with its advertising-in an attempt to confuse the public of Australia, to put fear into the public of Australia and to mislead the public of Australia. For example, Senator Bolkus would have us believe that all television advertising would cost $13,000 per minute, and that is what he said in this chamber recently. He uses this cost to justify the ban he proposes to make on free speech.

Mr Deputy President, you probably do not need me to tell you this because you come from Queensland and you know about the Brisbane City Council campaign, but the ALP in that campaign advertised for about 90 minutes on the television. If we multiply 90 minutes by $13,000 per minute, which Senator Bolkus says it costs, we find that the ALP spent over $1m to win the Brisbane City Council campaign. That is incredible in anyone's language. I am sure that the ALP in Queensland did not spend over $1m to win the Brisbane City Council election because, quite frankly, it never expected to win it anyhow and it would not throw that sort of money around. Even as wealthy as the Queensland ALP is, it would not spend that much money on a campaign to win the Brisbane City Council election.

What is even more incredible, if one uses Senator Bolkus's figures, is that in Townsville certain ALP candidates for the City Council also had a total of 80 to 90 minutes on television. No-one can suggest to me that the ALP spent $1m on winning the Townsville City Council campaign. It is absolutely ridiculous. But those are the sorts of figures that the ALP, Senator Bolkus and his other minions would have us believe in an attempt to get support around Australia for the ban on free speech which he is trying to impose.

Of course, the real situation with television advertising is that in my city of Townsville one can get 30 seconds on Tonight Live with Steve Vizard-not a show I watch but one which many people do. Mr Vizard was this year's Gold Logie winner and one can get 30 seconds of advertising on his show for $25-not $25,000 as Senator Bolkus would have us believe. So if a person wants to run an advertisement on Townsville television in prime time for a minute it will cost $50, not $13,000 as Senator Bolkus would say.

I know that prices are different with different television stations, and certainly at prime time in Sydney one may well pay a lot more. But to run around as Senator Bolkus does and have us believe that all political advertising is that expensive is ridiculous, and it puts the lie to the argument that the ALP has been proposing. Mr Deputy President, can you imagine that any little group should be prevented from putting their message across at election time?

There is a little conservation group on Magnetic Island called Island Voice. It advertised in the last Townsville City Council election. The sort of legislation that the ALP and this Government want to bring in would prevent that conservation group and hundreds or thousands of other groups throughout the nation from having their say in the way electoral campaigns are run.

History is full of governments that have attempted to restrict freedom of speech, and history is also full of the dictatorships that have followed the restriction of those liberties. This restriction, one would say, is only a small one but that is what used to be said in the other totalitarian regimes. It is only a little restriction now, but it is the first step. It should never be allowed to happen in our nation. There should never be any permission for any restriction of free speech.

If Senator Bolkus and the ALP wanted to do something to clean up political advertising, wanted to do something sensible and genuine, he would have got his Party to instil a little honesty into its election advertising-never mind about the electronic media, but in any media at all. What gives the ALP the right to use the sort of dishonest advertising that it has used very effectively in the campaigns in the local government elections in Queensland? I just show the Senate an advertisement that appeared in the Townsville Bulletin just before the election. Headed, `What services would the Liberals cut?', it suggested a number of things that the Liberal Party, if successful in the Townsville City Council campaign, would cut. It asked whether Liberal Party members would cut the 85 per cent pensioner rate rebate, whether they would cut the extension to bikeways, and whether they would cut the program to shoulder seal all Townsville streets. That is what the advertisement suggested.

The advertisement is completely dishonest because the Liberal Party policy in that campaign, as the ALP well knew, promised to retain all those services. But that did not stop the ALP, with its dishonest and misleading advertising, from running that sort of campaign. If the ALP wants to clean up political advertising, that is where it should start, not by banning free speech and political advertising.

Why do we not have a code of conduct in election advertising that prevents that sort of misleading statement? If that sort of statement were made about a product or service-something in the commercial world-the Trade Practices Commission would be down on the responsible company like a ton of bricks; it would be sued, fined and made to pay damages for that sort of misadvertising and misstatement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted against it.

—We did not vote against it. I am glad that Senator Lees is here. I am not quite sure what the Australian Democrats' policy is; it changes every five minutes. I understand that she has been told by the lefties and greenies who control her Party that she has to vote for us, which is pleasing. That is what we need. I hope that, when the crunch comes, the Australian Democrats will realise that it is that sort of advertising that should be banned and not electronic advertising. I take it from her nodding that she will support that and allow electronic advertising on the radio and television to proceed completely and freely. I am very pleased to see that and I congratulate her for taking that line. Let us just hope when the votes come that she continues that consent. I look forward to the day when the Democrats will have that fire and that strength of backbone to support us on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP proposal to ban free speech on television and radio but to allow it in other areas is equally ridiculous. I suggest that that will not ensure honesty in advertising and it will not ensure that the ALP will not get up to its dishonest tricks. I will show how the ALP cheats and lies in its direct mail advertising, which would still be legal under the ALP proposal. Have a look at this letter, Mr Deputy President. You can see that it is printed in Liberal blue colours. Anyone in the Townsville electorate receiving that letter would see the Liberal blue colours and think that it was from the Liberal Party. Of course the ALP is not mentioned anywhere. I admit that Alderman Mooney, the mayor, is mentioned, but many people would not know that he was the mayor and that he was from the ALP. Nowhere in that letter is there any indication that it comes from an ALP candidate. It is printed in Liberal blue with not one word mentioning the ALP.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last two Federal elections were just the same.

—The last two Federal elections were pretty much the same, as Senator Knowles said. The ALP is on the nose so it even pinches our colours in an attempt to give some credibility to its campaign. Mr Deputy President, if you think that is bad, I will take you back to the Brisbane mayoral campaign. In that respect I will quickly read a passage from each of three letters. The first letter from the ALP candidate for the Gabba says:

SPEECH.PARA: Only Labor is committed to stopping the proposed bridges into West End and Highgate Hill/Dutton Park, which would have a devastating impact on our community.
In one ward along the Brisbane River, the ALP is going to stop this bridge. Lo and behold, we get one from the Alderman for Doboy. He says in his direct mail letter:
So do not expect any better treatment from the Liberals when they consider the ill-conceived cross-river Bridge proposal for Hawthorne/Bulimba.
That is 10 miles downstream. So we have two bridges across the Brisbane River being proposed by the Liberals. Then the ALP candidate for Fairfield says:
And now they are planning to put A BRIDGE ACROSS THE RIVER to St Lucia. That will bring even more traffic into the suburb.
So we now have the ALP telling us that the Liberals are proposing to build three bridges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three bridges.

—Senator Jones can follow me. Not once did the Liberals ever say anything about bridges across the river, but this sort of dishonest, direct mail advertising would lead one to believe that that was the proposal. That is dishonesty in its greatest degree. And the Labor Party wants to talk about banning free speech. If we had free speech, those sort of claims would be corrected. If they are sneaked through as direct mail in the last days of the campaign, the other parties have no chance of refuting them. If those claims were made on television, a response could be made within a couple of hours. Within a couple of hours people would know that there was no way in the world that the Liberals would have proposed three bridges. I have only three letters, but I will bet that there were others that would have had the Liberals proposing 10 bridges all the way down the river. That is dishonesty in its greatest degree.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other examples, but time will not allow me to go into those. The ALP says that it is too expensive to advertise on television so it will ban it, but it will not ban advertising in the media or by way of direct mail. As a result there is a proliferation of that sort of claptrap and blatant dishonesty in this field. There is no way of correcting that just before an election if that is done a day or two before the poll. That is why it is essential that we retain the right of free speech, the right to say at all times what the real policies are and to refute the sorts of lies that our political opponents are very good at putting across. I just hope that the Democrats listen to that, understand it and, when it comes to the vote, they do not again crawl over with the Government, come to some compromise and sell their souls in some way that allows the ALP to ban free speech. I hope that that salutary lesson will be accepted by the Democrats and that they will join us to defeat the Government's proposals to ban electronic advertising so that 23 March 1991 will not become the last election day on which there was free speech in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. At no time have the Australian Democrats in any way supported dishonest advertising. Indeed, it was only the Democrats who opposed the removal in 1984 of the section of the Commonwealth Electoral Act that allowed examples such as those which Senator Macdonald quoted to occur. So it was the Liberal Party who supported the Labor Party to allow the licence to lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all very indebted to Senator Macdonald this evening for bringing to our attention some of the outrageous direct mail letters which the Australian Labor Party (ALP) used in the recent Brisbane mayoral campaign. It is not surprising for those of us who went through the last Federal election campaign to learn from Senator Macdonald that the ALP has played fairly loose and fast with the truth in relation to its direct mail letters. Probably millions of letters were posted out into marginal electorates in the last election campaign claiming, quite untruthfully, that the Liberal Party of Australia was about to abolish Medicare. Of course that was not the case, but it was designed to be part of the campaign of the big lie-the scare campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments by Senator Macdonald have underlined just how important ethics are in politics. The subject of ethics is a big matter of public debate at the moment. The greatest protection that we have is that people act in an ethical and proper manner. I suspect that it will be very hard for any law in the land to stop the filing of these direct mail letters which contain gross untruths. Therefore, Senator Macdonald has underlined in a very important way that one of the best counters to these types of letters, that unfortunately the ALP has made a practice of sending off, is for the party that feels aggrieved to respond on television. For example, the leader of the Liberal Party in the last Federal election had to go on television and make the point time and time and again that the Liberal Party was not about to abolish Medicare.

As I said, I think that effectively underlines the fact that it is important for political parties to have that right-that access to television and radio-to be able, among other things, to correct the misleading statements which have so often marked direct mail campaigns in recent years.

I want to speak briefly tonight about ethics and public policy. I want to draw the Senate's attention to what can only be described as an extraordinary statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the other place last Tuesday. When speaking to the condolence motion on the death of Sir John Kerr, he made the following statement:

The fact of the matter is that the Labor Party makes the political heroes in this country. When people cross the Labor Party they wear the crosses it puts on them, whether it be Billy Hughes or Joe Lyons-that is the truth of it. Sir John Kerr has worn the admonition of the Labor Party.
That extraordinary statement was made by Paul Keating in the chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! `Mr Keating', thank you, Senator Kemp.

—That statement was made by Mr Keating in the other place last week. I do not think that the first part of that statement, that the Labor Party makes the political heroes in this country, is correct. I do not think it was the Labor Party that made Deakin a hero; I do not think it was the Labor Party that made Sir Robert Menzies a hero; I do not think it was the Labor Party that made Reid, Parkes, Wentworth and so forth heroes. I think there are, indeed, many examples-tens of examples-where our political leaders who have earned the great respect of the public of the day, and that, after all, is the important test, have become political heroes, not because of the activities of the Labor Party.
—What about Rex Jackson? Did they make him a hero?
—I thank Senator Macdonald for drawing our attention to another extraordinary Labor Party figure.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw the Senate's attention to the latter part of Mr Keating's statement that `when people cross the Labor Party they wear the crosses it puts on them, whether it be Billy Hughes or Joe Lyons-that is the truth of it'. It has to be pointed out that Lyons and Hughes were two of our longest serving Prime Ministers. Our ALP colleagues may not be aware that Lyons and Hughes won more election victories out of the Labor Party than within it.

It also has to be mentioned that there are three Governors-General in Australian history who are sometimes noted for their close associations with the Labor Party: Sir William McKell, Sir John Kerr and Bill Hayden. For those ALP members who forget the McKell era, and think that the treatment of Sir John Kerr was unique in Australian history, let me remind the Senate that Sir William McKell was sent to Coventry by ALP members because he agreed to a double dissolution proposed by Menzies. Both of those Governors-General were punished in a vindictive way because they took decisions in the national interest.

My second observation is to suggest that the type of threat we heard from Paul Keating, I regret to say, is more typical of a mafia-type organisation than a major political party. Honourable senators should remember that `when people cross the Labor Party they wear the crosses it puts on them, whether it be Billy Hughes or Joe Lyons-that is the truth of it'.

I wish to canvass very briefly the significance of Mr Keating's statement and what it may mean to the independence of our institutions and the functioning of our democracy. The Treasurer is not a man to make ill considered statements. We may disagree with the content of what he says, and the arguments he puts forward, but Paul Keating does not make statements without knowing their full import.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp.

—Mr Keating does not make statements without considering their full import. Mr Keating is aware that the Labor Party is in a period of acute stress. The pressures on the Labor Party are coming from all directions-we have royal commissions in three States; we have a period of major public policy failure in relation to the Hawke Government, and the current recession which its policies have plunged us into; we have unbelievable levels of incompetence from Labor governments in the States of South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia; and, finally, we have pressures on the Labor Party resulting from the fact that the current Labor leadership has dropped many of the key principles which have guided and energised the Labor Party faithful for most of its history.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, we are seeing the collapse of voter support for the Labor Party; a haemorrhaging of Labor Party membership; bitter policy disputes between factions; and an increasingly divided and disloyal Cabinet. This is the context in which Mr Keating made his statement that when people cross the Labor Party they wear the crosses it puts on them.

That brings me to my next point. It is no secret that this Government has made a practice, unmatched by any other government in Australian history, of providing jobs for Labor Party members, its sympathisers and supporters. Many of these people now occupy senior positions in our major institutions. I do not make an accusation in this chamber that they are not honourable men but, like all of us, they will be judged on how they perform their duties. Party affiliation offers no protection nor does it in any way diminish their responsibilities.

Many of these people that the Labor Party has appointed-its sympathisers, members and former members-are in responsible positions, and may be faced with issues which require them to decide whether their loyalty is to the institution to which the Hawke Government has appointed them or to the Labor Party. Is their duty to the nation or to the ALP? Mr Keating has told us that, in his view, their duty is to the ALP. Will former trusted Labor Party stalwarts turn their backs on the party? We do not know the answer to that question, that is in the future, but we do know that Australia is in a serious economic and political crisis-a crisis unmatched in the memory of certainly most people in this chamber. Strange and difficult pressures, are placed on people in these times.

I suggest to the chamber that Mr Keating has fired the warning shots of a desperate man. His philosophy urges known Labor Party members and sympathisers appointed to major posts and boards to adopt partisan policies. Mr Keating does not understand how his incredible statement has left those people open to suspicion and odium. I suggest to the Senate that Mr Keating's philosophy is not appropriate to any governing party, let alone one which so relentlessly appoints its own sympathisers to positions of responsibility in the major institutions of this nation.

No coalition leader, I am proud to say, has ever claimed that the primary loyalties of individuals that it appoints to great positions are to the coalition. Every reference in the coalition platform shows that, as a political force, it is dedicated to Parliament and the rule of law. Mr Keating is saying, `You step out of line, you will be punished. You will have the judgment of the Labor Party on you. You will wear the cross that will mark you for life as an object of hatred and vindictive revenge. So be careful. In these difficult hours, remember, you owe your loyalties to the Labor Party not to the institutions which have been entrusted to your responsibility'.

I have no doubt that most Labor Party appointees will recognise their duties above partisan loyalty. At the end of the day maybe even Brian Burke will recognise his duty. I say this because we have greater traditions in this country than loyalty to the Labor Party, which influenced most Australians-Liberal and Labor alike.

The first of these is that Australians give a great priority to institutional and national loyalties rather than party political loyalties. The second set of traditions relates to the desire of most Australians to do what is right, proper and decent and if this may quarrel with a party political loyalty, so be it. The third tradition goes to the very core of our democracy, the desire of our people to avoid extremist positions either of the Right or the Left and to treat with disdain political zealots and power hungry politicians.

Mr Keating's threats will not quell the storm. The Labor Party is in disarray and he is shouting into the gale. If Australia is to make it through this crisis, it will not be because people in high places put the Labor Party above the national interest. We should be grateful to Mr Keating for one thing-for bringing to the attention of this Parliament a number of great Labor leaders who could no longer tolerate Labor ideology and Labor policies in times of national crisis. Paul Keating has drawn our attention to these leaders who, when faced with a crisis, chose the nation rather than the ALP.

No-one would argue that these men, Hughes and Lyons, did not do what was right by their own conscience and guidelines. To draw on Mr Keating's terminology, to wear the cross has never been a mark of dishonour in our society. Time and time again, Hughes and Lyons, flying colours other than those of the Labor Party, received what matters most in a democracy-the people's support. In contrast to Mr Keating's view, Hughes and Lyons are honoured in Australian history; so is Sir William McKell, as indeed will be Sir John Kerr. Mr Keating's threat should be treated with contempt by all who treasure democracy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 proposes the imposition of a supervisory levy on superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts which are subject to supervision by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The levy would be due and payable upon lodgment of annual returns with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner in accordance with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. The proposed levy would replace the present system of charging funds and trusts with a fixed fee (which is presently set at $40).

Honourable senators will recall that the Government announced in its August 1990 Budget Statement, that the fee would be replaced with a new levy commencing with the annual returns for the 1990/91 year of income.

The Government's intention in introducing this measure is to effect full cost recovery for the supervision by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of the superannuation industry. When the Insurance and Superannuation Commission was established in 1987, the Government decided to recover the costs of superannuation supervision and a lodgment fee of a flat $30 was set. Costs recovered under that fee have only recovered approximately half of the costs of relevant superannuation functions because the number of funds lodging returns has been less than half what was expected, from Taxation Office records.

This Bill, together with the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991, would give effect to the Government's Budget announcement. There are two Bills because the supervisory levy is a tax and, as such, must be imposed under a separate Bill. This Bill should be read as one with the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill and is to come into operation on the day the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill receives Royal Assent.
The Bill provides for the superannuation supervisory levy to have two components, a basic levy amount and a late lodgment amount.

The Bill provides for the basic levy amount to be prescribed by regulation. It is intended that the amount of basic levy payable would generally be determined on the basis of fund or trust asset size although, where appropriate, other bases for determining the levy may be used. Small funds (those with assets of $0.5m or less) would pay a levy which approximates only the cost of actually processing the forms as this closely approximates the call of those funds on Insurance and Superannuation Commission resources.

Large funds would pay a larger levy, generally depending on fund size, with a maximum levy applying at a level which would recoup all of the relevant costs. It is important to note that it would be possible to impose different scales of levy on different categories of funds or trusts. Thus, it would be possible, where appropriate, that superannuation funds might pay a different scale of levy compared to pooled superannuation trusts or approved deposit funds.

This Bill, being the Bill which imposes the levy, is required to set a statutory upper limit to the amount which it would be possible to impose on an individual fund or trust in any one year of income. The maximum levy limit set by the Bill is $30,000. This would amount to a very large increase over the current flat fee, although proportionately it is comparable to the payment of $40 in the case of a fund with $0.5m in assets. In practice, the amount of the maximum levy that will generally apply to funds and trusts in the first few years of operation will be well below this amount. I expect that the maximum levy imposed by regulation for the first year or so of operation would be of the order of $5,000.

The Bill provides for a late lodgment amount to be added to the basic levy amount when a return is lodged after a grace period of 14 days following a lodgment date specified by the Commissioner. The proposed period of grace is intended to allow a reasonable time for correction of returns which were attempted to be lodged on or before the relevant date but which were not complete (for instance in circumstances where a trustee has omitted to sign a return).

The late lodgment amount would be calculated on a monthly basis, at a rate of 20 per cent per annum of the basic levy prescribed for the particular fund, subject to a minimum monthly amount. The late lodgment amount is not a penalty and is intended to encourage timely lodgment of returns and to recover the additional costs associated with processing returns which are lodged late.

The large majority of the funds that will lodge a return would pay the minimum basic levy. If in the first year of operation, the minimum basic levy amount were $40 then the minimum monthly late lodgment amount would be $5.

Preliminary discussions are currently underway between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and industry representatives concerning an appropriate progressive scale for the basic levy which would apply to returns in respect of the 1990/91 year of income.

There would be annual discussions with the industry when the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is determining the scale of levies. In addition there would be annual consultation between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Department of Finance in determining the amount of revenue required to fully recover all costs.

For the first few years, until accurate asset profiles of funds and trusts are available, it will be difficult to accurately estimate the revenue which would be generated each year by a prescribed levy which is graduated according to asset size. Also, the precise amount of revenue that would be required to be raised in the first year of the levy, to fully recover relevant costs of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and based on the relevant current functions of the Commission, has yet to be confirmed.
It is estimated, however, that the amount required to be raised by the basic levy in the first year or two would be of the order of $6m to $8m: these amounts are therefore estimated revenue targets.
The revenue estimates do not include any estimate of revenue which might be generated by the late lodgment amount.
If the current flat $40 fee were continued, it is estimated that revenue would be of the order of $3.6m.

The arrangements I have just outlined, together with a provision for rounding up to the next whole dollar would also simplify the calculations necessary to determine the total levy to be paid. It is envisaged that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission will produce a simple ready reckoner for this purpose to which trustees would be able to refer. In addition, the arrangements outlined would facilitate the streamlining of annual return processing within the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
I commend the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill to the Senate, and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION SUPERVISORY BILL LEVY 1991OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 and the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991 and the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 are designed to give effect to a single purpose and that is a decision announced in the last Budget to achieve full cost recovery for the supervision of the superannuation industry by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. This is to be done by the introduction of a levy to be paid on the lodgment of annual returns, and that levy will depend upon the size of the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The fee of $40 which is currently applicable to all annual returns is likely to remain the fee for small funds-those with assets of less than half a million dollars. Those above that figure are likely to be looking at a levy of $5,000 a year in the first instance up to a maximum of $30,000 under the present legislation. Whilst the Government has given assurances to the industry that it will consult extensively before it seeks to increase those fee levels, we will be moving an amendment to ensure that full and proper consultation take place with the relevant peak councils, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia.

We take the view that it is desirable that a user pays principle should apply in this area and as a result that the industry will have not only the financial responsibility for funding the activities of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner but also an ability to exercise leverage in ensuring that the Commissioner fully undertakes his responsibility. So, at the end of the day, if something goes wrong, it will not be the fault of the industry.

Mr Beetham, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, has made it very clear that he welcomes that challenge. In his recent address to the Conference of Major Superannuation Funds in Wollongong, he spelt out very clearly the obligations which he believes ought to attach to the industry and the role that his office is prepared to play in ensuring that adequate prudential requirements are in place. Mr Beetham is simply acknowledging, in many respects, a situation which is widely recognised in the community, that is, that the growth rates of superannuation funds have been verging on the exponential in recent years, to the stage where we are now looking at assets to the value of $124 billion on last count and which are estimated to reach some $600 billion by the turn of the century if Treasury is right.

The Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his usual hyperbolic fashion, has suggested we might be looking at $1,000 billion, but I think most sober industry observers prefer the view of the Allen Consulting Group Pty Ltd which recently released its report Superannuation 2000 and its significant figure is something of the order of $350 to $400 billion. Even that is a trebling of the current level of assets over a 10 year period. It means that this industry will undoubtedly be one of the fastest growing industries and one that will need extraordinarily close supervision.

Make no mistake: there are many forces at work that will try to interfere with the proper commercial activities of superannuation funds. Not only the Treasurer, but also the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), are at this very moment seeking to do their best to direct the way in which superannuation funds make their investments-not in the crude manner that one might have expected if they were simply to be giving adherence to the Australia Reconstructed proposal of the Australian Council of Trade Unions or to some of the more gung ho resolutions emanating from the Caucus which has directed that a proportion of funds be invested in everything from low cost housing to large scale social infrastructure to venture capital through to a whole range of other so-called socially desirable projects.

We are likely to see some heavying on the part of leading Ministers to the point where a number of the major players, the life offices, are put in a position where they will be publicly criticised, probably vilified and condemned, for not exercising their national responsibilities and for going along with these sorts of proposals. I view with a great deal of concern the attempts that are being made at the moment to desperately get the Labor Government off the hook. It is trying to restart the economy by gaining access to the hard earned savings of very many small players-those people who have had the prudence and the foresight to save for their own retirement. They are overwhelmingly in the majority of those who are long term beneficiaries of superannuation. Those people are the ones who are going to be at risk.

It is probably part of the mythology fostered by the Australian Labor Party that industry funds are where it is all at; that, as a result of award superannuation, the vast majority of people are getting superannuation benefits that they have not had before. There are something like 100,000 company funds and fewer than 100 industry funds. The great majority of people are beneficiaries of traditional employer sponsored company funds and those are the ones that will make or break the future of superannuation in this country and they are the ones that will control, through their trustees, the manner in which those funds are invested.

It is not only irresponsible but also socially undesirable for the Government to be trying to usurp the role of the trustees of those funds, yet that is precisely what is being attempted at the present moment. I think it ill behoves the Labor Party to be in any way critical of others unless it is prepared to stand aside and give the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner full power, authority and funding and let him get on with the job.

We favour fuller disclosure than exists at the present time. We favour tighter prudential controls. We are anxious to ensure that this industry remains as safe as it can possibly be-certainly safe from the predations of those in the Labor Party who want to get their hands in the honey pot. I am reminded of a recent newspaper article from the State of Western Australia which demonstrates graphically the gap between rhetoric and reality in this area. That article, which appeared in the West Australian of 6 April, disclosed that there is a massive $3.9 billion shortfall in unfunded liabilities for the Government's Employee Superannuation Board. Indeed, the article says that another State-run shipping line, Stateships:
revealed in its latest accounts that its true superannuation liability had been assessed at $29.3 million, matched by a provision of only $5.5 million.

So Labor governments are in a position to lead the way. They are in fact able, if they choose, to ensure that there is proper and adequate demarcation in terms of the roles of trustees so that investment policies are undertaken by people with commercial experience who know what they are doing, who are best placed to make proper commercial judgments-they are not to be lent on or heavied in the public arena into putting all of their money into one area or another-and who do not put their money into things that are somehow the current flavour of the month, which some Ministers, for the benefit of their own political agenda, believe it is desirable for superannuation funds to take risks on.

I hope that as a result of the passage of these two Bills we see a much greater recognition of the imperative that these funds ought to be left to operate on commercial considerations. The spotlight of the regulator ought to be constantly upon them so that they are accountable for their actions but, ultimately, they should make the decisions and not the politicians. I think that is quite a considerable distance from the position we have at the present time.

Therefore, we favour proposals which will lead to greater prudential standards. Indeed, the Treasurer announced not so long ago that he had asked the Commissioner, the Treasury, the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Securities Commission, the Reserve Bank of Australia, and the superannuation industry to conduct a review of the superannuation industry. We welcome that and we think that simplification of the rules is a very important priority in this area. But we again express considerable concern at the way in which Mr Keating is endeavouring to demonstrate that somehow the funds are being irresponsible in the nature of their investments.

The fact is that less than 20 per cent of the assets of superannuation funds are invested in all types of real estate, despite the fact that the usual justification trotted out is that it is about time we stopped superannuation funds from putting all of their resources and reserves into central business district real estate. That is a myth. The funds themselves are very much aware that they need to have balanced portfolios and that it is highly desirable to have a spread of investments if they want to balance the rewards and risks. I have no doubt that we will continue to see responsible decisions being made by the vast majority of trustees.

If that is the case, the last thing they want is Mr Keating standing on the sidelines trying to twist their arms and somehow suggesting that their current investment strategies are not sufficiently gung ho, innovative or imaginative-as he has described it in the past. Indeed, we ought to welcome the fact that the trustees have been conservative in their investment policies; that they have taken heed of the October 1987 crash; and that they have not been out there leading from the front with funds which are not their own-nor, of course, the Government's funds.

The Opposition will support each of these Bills, but we will be anxious to ensure that the Government keeps it word: that it does not even contemplate going beyond the indicative level of about $5,000 for large funds without full and thorough consultation with the relevant industry bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is debating cognately the Occupation Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 and the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991. One of the purposes of these two Bills is to impose a new supervisory levy structure on superannuation funds pursuant to an announcement made in the last Budget. Constitutional requirements mean that two Bills are necessary. I will return to that point in a moment. The other matters dealt with in the legislation concern a late payment penalty to apply to unpaid levies, the taxation treatment of late lodgment penalties, electronic provision of data, the imposition of a fee for a copy of a previous reasonable benefit limit determination, and the discretion to not issue a compliance notice where a levy remains unpaid.

SPEECH.PARA: The Insurance and Superannuation Commission was established under a similarly named Act in 1987. This Commission supervises the insurance and superannuation industries. The Government has always intended to operate the Commission on the full cost recovery basis. A $30 fee was instituted on the annual returns lodged by superannuation funds from 1987, and similar levies operate on life and general insurance companies.

The superannuation levy was increased to $40 for the 1990-91 financial year. The revenue from the existing fees does not, however, cover fully the operation of the Commission, and the Government now proposes to adopt a fee based on the assets of the superannuation funds to replace the current flat fee. The current Budget estimates total outlays of $11.3m for the Commission and receipts of $8.6m, yielding a deficiency of more than $2.5m. The Bill's proposals are estimated to raise between $2.4m and $4.4m in extra revenue, thereby effecting the Government's goal of self-sufficiency and full cost recovery for the Commission.

It is noteworthy, however, that the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) describes the levy increase as necessary to recover the costs of superannuation functions. This statement actually directly contradicts the data contained on page 86 of the explanatory notes for the Treasury portfolio which shows outlays of $3.8m and revenue of $3.6m for the superannuation subprogram. This means that the superannuation funds are actually in balance and it would suggest to me that the shortfall must lie in other charges-possibly management services-and that that is now to be met by these Bills in order to achieve self-sufficiency.

I think this sloppiness in the second reading speech is indicative of the approach that the Government has taken to this Bill. We find that the delegation which the Government is proposing-in this case, for this levy to be established by regulation-is entirely unacceptable. The detail of the exact method of calculation has simply not been finalised. The Bill merely replaces the existing $40 fee with a maximum levy of $30,000. In the Minister's second reading speech we are told that it is expected that the maximum amount to be imposed will actually be about $5,000; so we have here a range of between $5,000 and $30,000 to be put into effect by regulation.

The Australian Democrats find that this is an unacceptable level of delegation. All the details are to be contained in regulations, we are told; yet it is obvious that the policy and the formula on which the calculations are to be based have not been finalised. The Minister's speech only states:
It is intended that the amount of basic levy payable would generally be determined on the basis of fund or trust assets although, where appropriate, other bases for determining the levy may be used.

One may well ask: what are these other bases for determining the levy? When would these bases be more appropriate than the asset-based approach? Fortunately, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is also disturbed by these proposals. We can be grateful for the valuable work of that Committee. The Committee has written to the Minister to clarify the matter but the Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this case, has not bothered to reply. I am told that this is not uncommon for the Treasurer. We believe that the current proposal should not be supported in its present form. The Australian Democrats are somewhat astonished that the Opposition, which always defends the primacy of the Parliament over the Executive in taxation matters, is prepared to accept these Bills in the current form.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee Alert Digest No. 4 of 1991 at page 18 accurately describes the problems which the Australian Democrats have with this legislation. Under the heading, `Inappropriate delegation of legislative power Paragraph 6 (1) (a)', it states:

Clause 6 of the Bill provides for the amount of levy to be paid by superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts in conjunction with the annual return which they lodge with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. Paragraph 6 (1) (a) provides that the `basic levy amount' is to be ascertained `in accordance with the regulations'.

The provision raises two possible concerns. First, the Committee questions whether this is an appropriate matter to be left for the regulations. The only guidance on what the regulations might contain comes from subclause 6 (5) which provides:
The regulations may provide the different basic levy amounts for different classes of funds or unit trusts.

Second, there is the question of whether this `levy' is more appropriately categorised as a tax. If it is more properly categorised as a tax then, clearly, this is a matter which should be dealt with by primary legislation and not by regulation.

In making this comment, the Committee accepts that subclause 6 (4) sets the maximum amount for the basic levy amount at $30,000. The specification in the legislation of a maximum levy or a formula for determining the maximum levy is a factor which generally tends to allay this Committee's concerns in this regard. However, the Committee notes that in the present case, in his Second Reading speech, the Minister states:

I expect that the maximum levy imposed by regulation for the first year or so of operation would be of the order of $5,000. If this is so, the maximum levy allowed under subclause 6 (4) is significantly higher than the amount which (at least initially) is expected to be set, leaving considerable scope for discretion in regulations subsequently made to alter the levy. In all the circumstances, the Committee would appreciate some guidance from the Minister on the reason that the clause has been drafted in this way.
The Committee draws Senators' attention to the clause as it may be considered to constitute an inappropriate delegation of legislative power . . .

The Democrats concur entirely with that view expressed by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It must be a matter of considerable concern that the Treasurer has obviously treated this advice and these queries from the Committee with utter contempt in not replying to this date, I am informed, to its concerns. I believe that it is up to the Senate to take a stand on such a matter, and the Democrats will oppose this Bill. We believe that we should not tolerate such a level of delegation and such a contempt by the Treasurer for the queries raised by a parliamentary committee.

All the other proposals are reasonable, with the exception of the proposed fee for a copy of a reasonable benefit limit determination. The relevant clause provides that the Commissioner must issue a determination, otherwise an individual will be charged income tax on the whole of his or her superannuation benefit. The proposal to levy a fee to provide a copy-and it is a copy-of such a vital document is, I believe, contrary to the freedom of information legislation and, indeed, to all principles of information legislation which should compel the Government to provide information on the personal details which pertain to each individual's concerns. We will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to delete this clause from the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991.

In concluding my remarks I shall advert briefly to some comments that were made by Senator Alston in which he spoke against any suggestion that superannuation funds should direct their funds to business in Australia to assist in the creation of jobs and generally to assist in internal capital formation. I refer to an article in the Australian newspaper on 6 February 1991 headed, `Super funds should be made to fund business'. The author of that statement is none other than Mr Adler, the Managing Director of the FAI Insurance Group. Mr Rodney Adler can be described as one of Australia's foremost businessmen and certainly an advocate of the free enterprise ethic, yet he says that the booming superannuation industry should be regulated to the extent that it is compelled, if it is not doing so of its own accord, to provide funds for the economic development of Australia and for the provision of jobs.

This legislation, while marginal to the overall regulation and supervision of the superannuation industry, is indeed a forerunner of other provisions and other legislation which will need to be introduced to ensure that this growing source of funds benefits all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Occupational Superannuation Laws Amendment Bill 1991 and the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Bill 1991.
