Rather than take the time of the Senate, perhaps it might be appropriate to signal my intention of taking this matter further during Senate Estimates committee hearings. But there is a genuine concern that there is lack of a uniform practice in relation to the manner in which those dividend imputation credits are offset.

I believe that the superannuation industry needs to be reassured by this Government that there will not be any further increases in the 15 per cent tax on the earnings of superannuation funds or on the cost of collections at source in respect of contributions derived from both the employer and employee. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to give an assurance in this respect because there are some rumours and concerns within the industry at present.

I see no problems with the technical aspects of the Bill and I have been informed that the industry welcomes the Government's assurance of full consultation each year prior to the setting of the annual fees by regulation. The industry believes that the levy approach is a reasonable price to pay to ensure the integrity of the industry so long as the Government honours its promise of ongoing industry consultation and so long as the ISC performs. So there are a couple of big question marks there.

I would like to take this opportunity to point out to the Government a number of areas of concerns and problems with superannuation in general that need attention. If the Government has decided that superannuation is to be the preferred medium for our old age, is it necessary that the Government should strive toward ensuring that the combined contribution is adequate to provide the necessary return? For example, at present the industry believes that the combined contribution needs to be something like 9 per cent to provide this adequate return. This raises several economic questions as to how the present economy under the Keating management will ever be able to achieve this need and at the same time bring this country out of an ever deepening recession.

I am also concerned that if superannuation is a preferred savings option for retirement, there should be a greater campaign on the part of the Government to encourage all employers to assume their responsibilities in this regard. It should not be up to the union movement or others. There are far too many employers who are not aware of their responsibilities. As a result, there is a building up of large amounts of arrears and penalties that will need to be paid eventually.

I also refer the Government to a report of the Strategic Issues Forum which was recently issued by the Committee of Economic Development of Australia. The report emphasises the need now to provide for the future. The report notes that the percentage of the population aged 65 years and over will more than double between now and the middle of the next century, while the ratio of workers to pensioners will almost halve. A definite possibility exists that revenue collected will not be sufficient for the payment of age pensions. That is, indeed, a sobering forecast.

The report recommends that policy initiatives be put in place to cover the predicted population trends. These include the abolition of compulsory retirement and the introduction of the universal superannuation scheme for workers; an increased emphasis on reskilling and training; and the diversion of assistance for the aged in the form of accommodation, leisure and education. The overall aim of the report states that the universal superannuation scheme should cover all workers, including those in private and public sectors, and the self-employed. A present limitation on the expansion of superannuation is that only employed persons are currently eligible to participate in private superannuation funds. Non-employed women and part time workers are disadvantaged by this ruling. This is an area which I believe needs certain investigation if universal superannuation is to apply. Hopefully, when the sex discrimination amendments finally reach this chamber, these sorts of problems will be debated.

The difficulty with most superannuation schemes is that the excess benefits tend to benefit those on the top salary scale. Those at the lower end of the scale tend to receive nil or low coverage. Therefore, I believe that, as part of this recognition of these problems, superannuation needs to be removed from the industrial to another area. In addition, although our present tax system encourages participation in superannuation, the converse is true when it comes to encouraging the average person to invest in long term savings other than superannuation. The interest on savings being taxed after it has already been taxed in the workplace is a major disincentive to the average taxpayer to invest in long term savings type investments.

I draw the attention of the Senate to a recent scheme commenced in the United Kingdom whereby interest on long term savings, that is, savings tied up for five years or more, is granted exemption from taxation. The scheme is known as TESSA, that is, tax exempt special savings account. The amount per year that can be invested in this type of account naturally is limited on a yearly basis as well as there being a maximum amount that can be invested. The interest shown in the accounts introduced since 1 January I think has surprised United Kingdom banks and building societies. Part of the cure for the recession-part only-and our alarming balance of payments is to increase savings whether this be by means of superannuation or other mechanisms. So the individual should always have the choice in how he saves his hard-earned cash. Superannuation should not be the only method of saving.

A further area that has caused me great alarm is the suggestion that a small proportion of superannuation fund money should be skimmed off by the Federal Government into risky ventures known euphemistically as venture capital projects. In simple terms, as suggested by one writer on this topic, `If Australian businesses will not put up the money, let us get it from the superannuation funds'. This is dangerous talk. To suggest that superannuation fund members should bear the full risk of businesses which have an excellent chance of going broke is simply outrageous.

The practical questions that arise if this is followed are quite numerous, for example, such questions as what is the legal structure of the body holding the money; who assesses the projects; how does one assess them; to whom is the body accountable especially if it loses a lot of money and the like; if it does not lose money why does it exist; who would be on the board of this body-indeed, who would be silly enough to accept an appointment to it.

I do not accept that everyday workers' retirement savings should be used for risky ventures. The choice of investment in venture capital should be left to the individual who can exercise his choice as to whether his savings can be put at risk. Consequently, he has the benefits of the gains and reaps the losses himself. The manager and trustees of pooled superannuation savings for everyday workers should not be forced to risk these hard-earned savings.

On the topic of the need to safeguard the retirement savings of the everyday Australian, I believe that the prudential rules covering the way in which superannuation funds can invest their members' money and engage in financial transactions need to be strengthened. At the moment superannuation regulations have clauses aimed at preventing funds from risking members' money. For example, superannuation funds are limited in what they can borrow from a company-run employers' superannuation fund.

The regulations also impose auditing standards and reporting requirements that stipulate actuarial reports every three years, but really do not go to the hard core of requirements in protecting and adequately providing a proper prudential standard that would provide a lot more assurance for those people who are putting money into superannuation funds.

The only force behind the regulations is the Commonwealth taxation powers, and superannuation funds are offered tax concessions provided that they abide by the superannuation regulations. Since the collapse of Occidental Life and Regal Life, it has been shown that this supervision may not be enough and has not been enough. Therefore, I repeat that there is an urgent need to update these regulations on prudential standards to ensure the safety of Australian savings in these sorts of investments.

Contrary to popular beliefs about superannuation funds investing in management investment companies-MICs-an alternative arrangements would be to encourage our funds to invest in safe overseas investments. This would soften our balance of payments problems because the more Australian superannuation funds invest overseas the greater the softening of the balance of payments. This would also apply to companies investing overseas. I know that there is some reluctance in some political quarters to encourage that because critics believe that funds should essentially be directed to Australian type investments. I know, for example, that one Australian company in the paper industry, Amco, has just made a further $20m investment in a corrugated paper supplier in the United Kingdom, taking that company's overseas investments and acquisitions past $500m. I remind the Senate that now over one-third of that holding company's sales come from offshore operations and substantially benefit our balance of payments. I remind the Senate that our foreign debt was small when the present Government came to power. It has since exploded by 468 per cent. When the coalition government was in power in 1972, there was a current account surplus of $754m.

In conclusion, I commend these Bills to the Senate. I look forward to receiving the answers to the four questions I posed earlier in my speech, but I hope that the Government will heed some of the wider concerns in relation to the superannuation industry. In particular, I look forward to the raising of prudential standards for superannuation funds.

The bounty will affect and benefit one firm only-Sirius Biotechnology located in Altona, Victoria, a company which closed its doors in late 1990 and retrenched its 34 researchers and technicians.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason given for the cessation of production was that the pricing scheme designed to protect Australian sugar growers had required the company to pay double the international price for the sucrose or the glucose necessary for its fermentation process. The net effect of this Bill will give effect to the owner of Sirius Biotechnology which will shortly be a multinational food and industrial conglomerate, Bunge Industrial Ltd, receiving $7.72m from the operation of the bounty.

The Government has determined that this particular biotechnology process must be preserved in Australia in order to provide a manufacturing base for the further exploitation of the production process. One might pose the question how it expects to achieve that. It contends that the retention of the plant and equipment is essential for the commercialisation of leading edge biotechnology research and development activities under way in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and various universities.

It appears that the presence of Sirius in the market has provided the momentum for this research and development program. Therefore, the Government sees the application of the bounty-be it uncomfortably selective and short-sighted-as a means to an end. Putting research and development aside for a moment, the question we must ask ourselves is whether this Bill will be of benefit to Australian companies and, in turn, to Australia, and whether this knee-jerk reaction is an appropriate measure to help keep and foster high tech industries in Australia. The answer on all counts is no. The Bill is set to affect one company only, and a foreign-owned company at that. It is a short term reactive measure to plug the holes in Australia's ailing high tech retention sieve.

The coalition parties are clear in their opposition to this Bill. At first glance, the Bill may appear reasonable, even sensible, and at any rate one could argue that the amount of $7.72m is trifling. But the coalition firmly believes that, small though it may be, the proposal is diametrically opposed to a gradual reduction in protection levels and a reduction in distortions in assistance between industries-objectives we thought had broad bipartisan support. Therefore, the coalition parties are opposing this Bill not because we do not consider that the fermentation technology developed is unique or worthwhile, but because it is a retrograde step in terms of industry policy. The position is based on the necessity for the Government to carry out reforms which will allow all industries to derive benefits, which will allow them to be competitively placed as import replacement or export industries.

The intention of the Bill, as put forward by the Government, is to provide an economic incentive for Bunge Ltd to retain the operation of its soon to be acquired citric acid fermentation plant in Australia. The point of the exercise is not, however, to see the development of the local citric acid production capability as such. It is rather to seek to ensure the presence in Australia of its production facilities which will enable Australia to further capitalise on its research and development strengths in fermentation-based biotechnology. The link is not between the bounty and the continuation of the research. It is rather, as I pointed out earlier, between the retention of the Altona factory and the possibility of commercial development of that research taking place in that plant.

Put simply, the Government is hoping, by way of the bounty, that the technology process embodied in the Sirius plant and production processes is not, in the short term, sold off overseas under licence, which will, the Government hopes, enable the industry to move closer towards the commercialisation of existing biotechnology research and development programs. However, it is also more than possible, given the company's prior financial investments, that Bunge would have retained its commitment to the research and development program regardless of the availability of the Sirius operation.

As my colleagues in the other place have made clear, the coalition parties in opposing the Bill do not do so on the issue of the biotechnology research effort which is under way in Australia. The value of the research work in this area is well recognised. However, we question the integrity of the process by which the Government is seeking to achieve the goal of preserving the production facilities in Australia, the implications of this in respect of the signals it sends to other private sector companies, and the capacity of the bounty to deliver its intended result-that is, its simple practicality.

Specifically, it should be recognised that Bunge Ltd may refuse to enter the bounty arrangement given our refusal to support the legislation. However, if it does enter the agreement, there is still no indication that it would retain its operations in Australia beyond the terms of the expiry date of the bounty. As I understand it, should Bunge Ltd decide to break the agreement with the Government at any point, it would not be liable for the repayment of the bounty that it has attracted. That means there is no guarantee that a suitable return will be forthcoming to the Australian community for its outlays. The exercise simply lacks sufficient transparency to justify the appropriation of public funds.

Despite a departmental briefing provided to the coalition, the coalition parties have not had access to sufficient information on the cost performance circumstances affecting Sirius to justify support for what is, in effect, a cash transfer payment. The explanatory notes make reference to the requirement that that company continue research and development, contribute to product development, explore new markets, and take all reasonable steps to provide for the participation of local companies. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce agrees that, whilst it is possible to determine whether these objectives are being carried out, the level of the commitment will be a matter for subjective assessment.

Putting it plainly, it is difficult to see what the Australian community will be getting in return for its outlay of in excess of $7m. This is exacerbated by the reported comments of the Chairman of Bunge Ltd, in which he is quoted as saying that Sirius `is a baby in the whole area' of fermentation technology and it would be a `big struggle' to develop a market for citric acid in Australia. Given this, the capacity of the future owner of Sirius, even with the injection of the bounty payment over the next four years, to build a competitive market position is in question.

The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce agrees that if Bunge Ltd is unable to compete in the citric acid market here and overseas, it will not maintain Sirius as a manufacturing base. That is, if Bunge determines at some point that it is still not in its interests to manufacture in Australia, it can up and go, and it can do this without repayment of the bounty that it has received.

Reflecting momentarily on the history of the company, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in his second reading speech attributed most of the cost disadvantage to this company to the price of sugar. He made an attempt to lay the blame for that set of circumstances on the coalition parties. He neglected to mention that his Government was happy to continue the sugar import embargo for six years before advocating its abolition. At any rate, the sugar tariff is being reduced and I understand that the company has switched to wheat gluten as its substrate. This weakens considerably the Minister's argument.

Beyond these concerns there is a larger question as to the merit of doing deals with corporate entities in order to retain their manufacturing or research bases in Australia. The Government has selectively chosen a single area of strategic development for assistance. As the benefits of the bounty are captured by only one company, it therefore technically represents an added and discriminatory cost to other users of the same raw materials. Whatever the merits of the circumstances of Sirius, one cannot escape the fact that the proposed bounty is a case of the Government picking, or attempting to pick, a winner. Given the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd fiasco, one would have thought that the setting of further precedents in this regard would have been avoided at all costs.

The benefits of the bounty accrue to a single company utilising a particular technology. It is extremely difficult to justify the decision to single out a particular technology for support over another. If this technology, why not the high-tech production facilities of Black and Decker (Australasia) Pty Ltd; why not offset costs impinging on the advanced ceramics program of ICI Australia Ltd? Why not take up public interest ownership in gene shears technology? Why not meet the cost impediments to the further development of an array of other technologies with, presumably, equal claim to strategic technological significance? Alternatively, why was support not given to retain the manufacturing presence of the medical manufacturing arm of Pacific Dunlop Ltd, Telectronics Pty Ltd? Telectronics shifted its manufacturing of the implantable pacemakers to Miami last year with a loss of over 200 jobs in Australia.

As we are all too well aware, the administrative process of selecting particular industries or technologies for special assistance is always reduced ultimately to politics and leaves itself wide open to special pleading, lobbying and even corporate blackmail. Once concessions of this sort are made, the Government has revealed its susceptibility to special pleading and, therefore, politicises the process by which it seeks to allocate resources. In the case of Kodak, which bears an obvious parallel to the initiative under consideration, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce implied that this was the case which proved the rule. It would now seem that it was the case which broke the rule. Of course, we have that circumstance of those funds going into Kodak. As I understand it, the Minister was asked on one occasion: how did Kodak receive such an allocation of government funds?
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to speak briefly on a very sad matter, namely, the death last Thursday of Dr Peter Rawlinson of La Trobe University, a former colleague, a very active conservationist and one who has performed extremely well in his academic area. I first came across Peter in the 1970s when we appeared together on a platform in relation to the adverse effects of agricultural chemicals. I also appeared with Peter on a number of occasions through the 1970s on public platforms and on a Four Corners program, I think as long ago as 1978. He was very concerned about the effects of such chemicals on the environment and on humans. He was very active in raising concerns, I recall, specifically over the substance 245-T.

SPEECH.PARA: Peter became a member of the Australian Conservation Foundation and in the last several years has been Treasurer of the Foundation. In that organisation he took an active interest in wildlife preservation and particularly the question of kangaroo populations and kangaroo culling. He was very active in a number of areas and operated against a very considerable background as a lecturer in biological sciences at La Trobe University. As I mentioned, he died last Thursday while on an expedition to a small island off the island of Krakatoa in Indonesia.

It is not generally recognised that science does not really establish absolute truths. Science is a way of looking at the world, a way of understanding the world in which we live. Science as such enriches our experience of the world around us. It should in that way make us much wiser people because it gives us a depth to our understanding of the world in which we live. It is unfortunate, however, that many scientists do not demonstrate this wisdom but rather make their services as scientists, or people trained in science, available to industry and particularly to the military industry. It is often said that over half the scientists in the world work in military science and a number of others become the unquestioning handmaidens of industry.

However, there are some scientists-Peter Rawlinson was one of these-who, with a deeper understanding of the world in which we live, undertake to attempt to build a much better world. That is why Peter actively engaged himself as a scientist in public debate on a number of issues of concern, and particularly those issues that have the potential either to build a better world for tomorrow or, on the contrary side, to damage the world in which our children will live.

In this respect Peter Rawlinson was, fortunately, one of a growing band of scientists who do not live in ivory towers-who come out of their ivory towers and make their knowledge, their wisdom and their understanding applicable to ordinary, everyday life, to participate in the processes of social decision-making and to work very actively in every spare moment towards a much better world.

Peter Rawlinson was only 48 when he died and his death is a very great loss to Australia. I understand that there will be a memorial service at La Trobe University on Saturday the twenty-seventh of this month. I would certainly enjoin all people who have a concern for building a better world, who know of the work of Peter Rawlinson, if they are in Melbourne at that time to make every effort to attend the memorial service. I understand that he is survived by a wife and two children-people whom I have never met. I believe that everybody will extend very deep sympathy to Peter's family. His death is a great loss and something that I know the conservation movement throughout Australia is feeling very deeply at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: -Recently some outrageous statements have been made by Mr Stephen Martin, Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I can only judge were designed to denigrate my credibility as a witness before the inquiry into the Australian banking industry and the evidence I tabled on that occasion, which I have tabled over the past 2 1/2 years and which I might subsequently table. SPEECH.PARA: For the moment, I simply draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that on 15 March I appeared before a bank inquiry which, frankly, I believe I had partially caused to be put in place by the processes I had been pursuing in this place for 2 1/2 years. I appeared before that inquiry as a principle witness, accompanied by a barrister of the High Court of Australia and a barrister of the Supreme Court of Victoria. We presented 3,000 pages of evidence to the banking inquiry, 1,500 pages of which I have tabled progressively over 2 1/2 years before your very eyes, Mr President, in support of 70 cases that I have brought to the attention of the Senate. In addition, I tabled 1,500 pages of new evidence that had never been sighted by the Senate or by the banking inquiry and tabled, in confidence, the names of two former senior officers of the Westpac Banking Corporation who were prepared to interpret those documents for the banking inquiry.

I did that on a Friday. Two days later, on a Monday, at the first available public opportunity in an address to the society of economists in Sydney, Mr Martin chose to denigrate my evidence. I was appearing merely as a witness, in the same way as hundreds of others were appearing before the inquiry, providing evidence which in many cases very learned lawyers in support of the cases of many seriously damaged constituents had helped prepare. Mr Martin chose to make a glib statement that I had failed to provide evidence. He has admitted to me that he had not read the evidence that I had put before the inquiry in the ensuing two days. In so denigrating my presence before his Committee and the evidence I had provided, I think he irrevocably damaged the process of parliamentary committee inquiries-a matter of deep and profound seriousness to our Parliament and something which should be addressed in serious debate by both houses of our Parliament. I will be attempting to ensure that that debate occurs.

I make these comments purely as introductory remarks. At the end of his statement, Mr Martin said, `McLean had better put up or shut up'. I thought that I had been putting up for 2 1/2 years, and I shall continue to put up tonight. Honourable senators will be relieved that I am returning to the process of tabling before this chamber and before the Parliament solid, substantive evidence of allegations which I have been raising, and will continue to raise, of banking malpractice and corrupt practices.

The first three cases I brought before this chamber were those of Batiste, Rigg and Taylor. I attempted to elaborate on those before the bank inquiry as examples of what I had referred to as targeting and asset stripping. Indeed, we tabled a lot of evidence, which presumably Mr Martin has decided will not in fact be regarded, addressed or considered by his inquiry. I will continue to put it forward tonight.

I return therefore to the matter of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd and to imprudent bank lending practices in relation to that company because I think that that is a classic case, substantiated and documented by me progressively, of bank malpractice and corrupt practices. I have demonstrated in this place how officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia painted their bank into a corner. During December 1985, senior management of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia assumed responsibility for the administration of the company's overdraft account. In a memorandum dated 16 December 1985, which I have referred to previously, the Assistant General Manager, Mr R.A. Hill wrote:

Senior Executive of this Administration became aware of the full situation in a memorandum of 5th December from Mr Simington . . . upon receipt of this memorandum the writer, in conjunction with D/C/M Mr Vanner, took the following action: Branch was informed that no further cheques were to be paid without reference to writer or D/C/M and all branches involved to be informed immediately of the stand being taken . . . Mr Burton, Deputy State Manager CDB--
that is, the Commonwealth Development Bank--
Sydney, has been fully acquainted with the situation and the stand being taken by the CBA . . . The matter is under the personal control of DCM, Mr Vanner . . .

I previously tabled that memorandum. It was among the documents, 1,500 pages of which I put before Mr Martin's Committee. The direction by Mr Hill was adhered to. In a memorandum, dated 23 December 1985, a senior manager of the New South Wales Southern Division, Mr K.M. Simington stated:

Cheques have been paid on a day to day basis but only if cash has been deposited to meet them . . . A number of cheques have been dishonoured with the answer ``Present Again'' but to date all cheques have been paid on representation.
I seek leave to table all of the documents from which I am quoting during the process of this debate.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that the Commonwealth Development Bank held a registered equitable mortgage over the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley Springs. One interest payment was due from the company to the Commonwealth Development Bank on 1 January 1986. If that payment was not met, the Commonwealth Development Bank could appoint receivers to the assets and undertakings of the company. If the payment for the interest was drawn against the overdraft account of the company, Mr Vanner could prevent the appointment of receivers by allowing payment to the Commonwealth Development Bank. Equally, Mr Vanner could refuse payment and the company would be in default to the Commonwealth Development Bank. The CDB was well aware of the implications if the interest was not paid. In a memorandum dated 31 December 1985, Mr K.I. Watson of the Commonwealth Development Bank head office wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The CBA are not paying cheques unless covered by funds lodged. So far Miss Batiste has been able to produce funds to cover, on representation, all cheques which have been dishonoured.
Proposed Action
Check on payment of interest of $5,930.00 which falls due on 1st January, 1986. If not met, Sydney office is to pursue payment as a matter of top priority.

New Year's Day was a public holiday. The Commonwealth Development Bank could expect payment on the following day, and that is what happened. Given the priority attached to the payment, one would expect the Commonwealth Development Bank to make any necessary presentation to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia for clearance of payment at the earliest practicable time. That apparently happened on 2 or 3 January. If for any reason the Commonwealth Bank of Australia did not meet the payments, one would expect alarm bells to be ringing at the Commonwealth Development Bank. Apparently, that did not happen. In addition, if there was nothing untoward going on, one would expect that the records of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank would coincide. They did not. The overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd at CBA's Park and Castlereagh Streets, Sydney branch, was number 2018-29-1976. I seek leave to table the account card.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bank statement on page 47 relating to that account has this entry: 2 JAN 86 CDB 5930.40. The entry represents payment of the interest to the Commonwealth Development Bank. Those who examined these documents will note that no cheque number is shown in the entry. This means that the company did not draw a cheque against the overdraft account payable to the Commonwealth Development Bank. That also means that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia would have drawn-that is, issued a bank warrant or other means of inter-bank transfer from its own account against a corresponding debit to the company's account. If that is what happened, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia could not dishonour or reverse the payment to the Commonwealth Development Bank. The bank statement on page 48 purports to show this entry: 3 JAN 86 REV 5930.40 I repeat the words `purports to show'. The reverse side of the account card shows entries entitled `Dishonours for lack of funds'. The purported dishonour of $5,930.40 does not appear on 3 January 1986 or at any later time. Further, the purported dishonour does not appear on Miss Batiste's account card, which I have previously tabled. I say that the reason that the purported reversal did not appear on the account card was that on 3 January 1986 there was no reversal and there was no dishonour. In support of that contention, I refer to a memorandum of the Commonwealth Development Bank, dated 8 January 1986, in which the State Development Bank Manager of New South Wales, Mr J.W. Thompson said to the Commonwealth Development Bank head office:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been informed by CBA Park and Castlereagh Streets that our drawing for $5,930.40 representing interest charged in December has been returned unpaid. This does not yet reflect in the balance of our account.

I emphasise those words: `This does not yet reflect in the balance of our account'. Why not? I suggest that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia had honoured the payment. Mr Thompson took the matter further on the following day. In a memorandum dated 9 January 1986, Mr Thompson stated:
At the request of the CBA, I attended a meeting at NSW Branches Administration on 8th January, 1986. Others present were:-
Messrs. Robinson, Vanner and Simington-CBA; and Ian Cambourne-Legal Department

. . . CDB details need amendment as drawing for December, 1985 interest (payable January, 1986) has been returned unpaid. Balance is thus now approximately $506,000.00 and the loan is now in default to the extent of the unpaid interest . . . The Company was still trading but on the previous day CBA had declined a request to provide further accommodation. It had in fact taken the decision that the company was in an irretrievable financial position and that CBA should serve demand as it was convinced it could not salvage the greater part of its $3Million involvement . . .
CDB was asked what it intended to do . . . I replied that should borrower decide to close down its plant and operations . . . CDB would serve demand on the company . . .

This means that the question of the dis-honour and reversal was raised by officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia in the context of the decision to pull the plug on Huon Valley Springs. What makes the meeting on 8 January so extraordinary is that at the time CBA held $350,000 of company funds on interest bearing deposits. This fact was well known by the Commonwealth Development Bank. In a memorandum dated 9 January 1986, Mr Thompson stated:
Total CBA involvement with the company is $1,236,361.00 for which the only tangible security is a T/D (that is, Term Deposit) of $350,000.00.

What this means is that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia had been placed in an untenable position because of its own imprudent lending practices and, in spite of the $350,000, was now going to `pull the plug' on Huon Valley Springs. What this also means is that the Commonwealth Development Bank was prepared to alter its records to show a default, in spite of the fact that its brother bank, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, had $350,000 on behalf of the company.

I contend that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia did not dishonour the payment and that the purported reversal is a fraud. I contend that when management of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia decided to `pull the plug' on the company, the overdraft account was manipulated and the records falsified to facilitate the appointment of a receiver.

The allegation that officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia manipulated an account and falsified records to facilitate proceedings against a customer is not new. That is what officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia did to Tony Rigg and his company. I pursued that case in this place and tabled that evidence before the bank inquiry.

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia had a problem. If the bank statement page 48 was to be falsified to show a reversal of $5,930.40, subsequent statements would have to be falsified to take account of the revised debit balance. That means that the original statements would have to be destroyed and replaced with false statements. Mr President, I draw your attention to the handwritten note on the company's account card: `Destroy original of statements'. Those words speak for themselves.

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia also had another problem. The officers of the CBA could hardly inform officers of the Commonwealth Development Bank how they were going to falsify the statements. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the adjournment debate. I think it is the first time I have ever done so as a senator. I take a fairly jaundiced view of people who speak for any length of time on the adjournment.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to record in the Hansard the passing early last week of Graham Greene, a great prolific writer in the English language, a great entertainer and a great storyteller. The fact of the matter is that he brought joy to many millions of people with his work, including over the years a number of senators whom I have seen reading Graham Greene novels in the chamber. For that reason, I wanted to make mention of this matter.

I do not have a prepared speech. But the well-known Graham Greene novels include Brighton Rock, The Quiet American, Our Man in Havana and The Heart of the Matter. Perhaps one of the greatest books of all time about spies and secret agents was The Human Factor. I believe that these books will remain classics in the English language for some time to come.

Graham Greene also wrote some great short stories. There is a volume called Travels with My Aunt and another in Penguin called Journey Without Maps. These are great short stories and I would have no hesitation commending them to bored senators who want to fill in time between two speeches or something of that kind with a little bit of light, elegant and beautiful entertainment. He also wrote a great autobiographical book called A Sort of Life which described the earlier part of his own somewhat rich and fascinating life.

Graham Greene was many things. He was a diplomat. I might be doing him an injustice, but I think he was a member of MI5 during the war. He was certainly involved in the intelligence business during the war. He was a great traveller. He spent months and years in other countries. In fact, I have a book at home called Graham Greene Country in which extracts from his diaries are illustrated with beautiful drawings of places such as Saigon, Singapore and the south coast of France to which he went and lived.
I do not wish to detain the Senate. I think the passing of Graham Greene should be recorded. I felt on the day it happened that the great prince had died and that that ought to be acknowledged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Given that the time lag is increasing for ``advance'' Taxation Office rulings, will the Government provide additional resources in the area to overcome the dilemma facing taxpayers having to cope with receipt of late rulings, self assessment and limited time intervals between year end, lodgement of return and payment of tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The major response of the Australian Taxation Office in relation to advance opinion requests has been to manage the process for providing answers as quickly and effectively as possible rather than to contribute additional resources to the task.

Performance monitoring applies to all requests which are dealt with through a branch or regional network with a performance indicator requiring answers to be provided within a month of receipt of the request.
Processes to analyse workloads and to devise strategies for dealing effectively with backlogs are currently being implemented and should result in an improved level of service to taxpayers.

More specifically, a recent meeting of the ATO with representatives of major professional and taxpayer groups, agreed that a standardised format would be used for rulings requests to ensure that all information is submitted with the ruling. This should assist in expediting settlement of a significant number of cases as delays have occurred in the past where inadequate information has been provided by some taxpayers.

In the longer term, the move towards a self assessment form of tax administration will benefit taxpayers as additional resources are freed from processing work. These resources will be available to provide a comprehensive and targeted range of services to ATO clients.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current annual cost to revenue of personal income tax deductions for work related expenses such as tools of trade, uniforms, reference books and so on.
(2) How is the present limit of $300 determined for these expenses before they must be substantiated.
(3) Is the limit determined by legislation or by a decision of the Commissioner of Taxation.
(4) What would be the annual cost to revenue of raising the specified limit of $300 to, for example, $400 or $500.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost to revenue in the 1988/89 income year of personal income tax deductions for work related expenses such as tools of trade, uniforms, car and travel expenses, reference books and so on is estimated to be $1350 million.

(2) The formal substantiation requirements do not apply where an employee's aggregate claims for work related expenses do not exceed $300 in the income year. Where the amount spent is less than $300, only the amount actually spent is claimable. A diary or other record should be kept to show how the claim was derived.

When introducing the substantiation provisions the Government weighed concerns regarding compliance costs against concerns regarding exploitation of areas of latitude in the tax system. In so doing, it formed the judgement that excluding from the formal substantiation requirements claims of up to $300 for work related expenses was a reasonable balance between concerns of compliance costs and preserving the integrity of the tax system.
(3) The $300 exclusion is provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act at Section 82kzb.

(4) A deduction is only allowed for the amount of expenses actually incurred in earning income. For this reason, any increase in the specified limit will not necessarily result in a corresponding increase in claims for work related expenses. It may, however, prompt some taxpayers to make inflated claims which would result in a cost to revenue. The cost to revenue to raising the limit would therefore depend on the number of taxpayers who inflate their claims to the new limit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What specific food items, if any, are subject to current wholesale sales tax.
(2) What, if any, clothing items are subject to the current wholesale sales tax.
(3) What are the total annual collections from the present wholesale sales tax.

(4) Is it likely that a broad-based consumption tax would apply to food and clothing in order to generate sufficient revenue both to abolish the present sales tax and to implement cuts in personal income tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Most food items are exempt from the current wholesale sales tax. However, the following food items are taxable at the rate of 10 per cent:
* confectionery;
* biscuits;
* ice-cream;
* savoury snacks such as chips, nuts, twisties;
* beverages which consist of not less than 90 per cent milk that contain flavouring;
* non-alcoholic Australian wine and cider;
* fruit juice products that consist of not less than 25 per cent by volume of juice of Australian fruits.
The following food items are taxable at the rate of 20 per cent:
* beer, wine, whisky, brandy and other potable spirits;
* carbonated beverages.
(2) Most clothing items are exempt from sales tax. However, articles made of fur skins such as fur coats, capes, caps, jackets and stoles are taxable at the rate of 30 per cent.

(3) The total annual revenue collections from the wholesale sales tax were $9,402 million in 1988-89, and $10,132 million in 1989-90. The budget estimate for revenue collections from the wholesale sales tax in 1990-91 is $10,668 million.

(4) As the Government has rejected implementation of a broad-based consumption tax, there has been no need to address possible inclusions or exclusions from such a tax base. However, as I have indicated on several occasions, it is not possible today to introduce a fully compensated consumption tax generating sufficient revenue to provide further reductions in marginal tax rates even where food and clothing are included in the tax base.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a specific air force instruction of 1989, Administrative Procedures for dealing with Homosexual Behaviour in the RAAF state, inter alia, `this policy ensures that when homosexual activity is suspected, the matter is handled discreetly, the members concerned are treated sympathetically, and the interests of the service are preserved'.

(2) What have been the changes in general RAAF practice in relation to dealing with suspected homosexual service personnel since the 1989 policy was promulgated and, in particular, in which ways have air force security police changed their practices in relation to suspected homosexual service personnel.

(3) Do air force security police practices in relation to suspected homosexual service personnel include surveillance of personnel suspected of being homosexual, the security police themselves operating under false names and identification and behaving in ways designed to entrap suspected personnel, and questioning of suspected personnel without an official caution being given.
(4) If any, or all, of the practices detailed in (3) are confirmed, is there a conflict between those practices and the public policy of the defence forces referred to in (1).

(5) If any, or all, of the practices detailed in (3) are confirmed, do those practices comply with Australia's obligations under ILO Convention 111 and the goals of the Federal Government's human rights legislation in relation to discrimination on the basis of sexual preference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) There have been no changes in RAAF practices since the 1989 policy was promulgated. Air Force Security Police carry out investigations discreetly and overtly. Courtesy and discretion are exercised so as to cause as little embarrassment to the member as possible.

(3) &(4) RAAF Police practices do not include surveillance of persons suspected to be homosexual. Such matters are handled by normal administrative means unless a criminal act is involved (e.g. sexual assault). In all cases where a suspected homosexual is interviewed by RAAF Police, they are afforded the full protection and rights afforded service personnel under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. The subject of criminality seldom arises.

(5) The practices referred to in Question 3 are not undertaken by Air Force Security Police and therefore do not contravene Australia's obligations under ILO 111 and the Federal Government's Human Rights Legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1990 (Hansard, page 3013) Senator Spindler asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning interest withholding tax. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The value of the exemption from interest withholding tax provided by section 128F of the Income Tax Assessment Act is estimated at $225 million for 1989-1990.

The rationale for the exemption has been that interest withholding tax would largely or fully reflect in interest rates in the markets to which the exemption applies, and, if imposed, would therefore represent an additional cost for Australian business. On this basis, the exemption does not directly increase the current account deficit.
Interest withholding tax involves market sensitivity and the Government will not comment on hypothetical changes to the tax.
